reviews.review_title: An absolute masterpiece- Pixar's best flick since the Toy Story series
reviews.content: *May contain spoilers* Pixar has done it again. After a few years of fluctuation in quality, Pixar has redefined what is possible in the art of animation. Inside Out, Pixar's 15th feature film, has combined the imagination the studio is renowned for, and a very real human quality- Emotion. Inside Out portrays an 11-year old girl, Riley Andersen(Kaitlyn Dias), along with her emotions, moving with her family from her home in Minneapolis, Minnesota to San Francisco. Riley's emotions, Joy(Amy Poehler), Sadness(Phyllis Smith), Disgust(Mindy Kaling), Anger(Lewis Black- A big fan already!) and Fear(Bill Hader) , keep Riley in check during these times using a console board that controls Riley. Sadness, seen as a nuisance usually by all the other emotions accidentally touches a memory contained in an orb, that was happy, turning it sad, and causing Riley to get upset in her new school. Chaos ensues as Joy tries to salvage Riley's core memories,each one powers a different aspect of her personality, and unfortunately, the core memories, along with Joy and Sadness, gets sucked out to the Long Term Memory.Meanwhile, the remaining emotions try to manage Riley in the absence of Joy and Sadness, causing her personality to gradually fail.Joy and Sadness, lost in the Long Term Memory, meet Bing Bong (Richard Kind), Riley's long forgotten imaginary friend. Bing Bong yearns to be remembered by Riley, and he agrees to direct the two emotions back to HeadQuarters, by riding the Train of Thought.Not all goes to plan, after traversing through Disneyland-like areas of Riley's mind, they eventually catch the train, however, the track collapses when one of Riley's personality islands disintegrates, which results in Joy and Bing Bong falling into the memory dump, a limbo of forgotten memories.She comes across a memory, which depicts a sad Riley seeking comfort from her parents after losing a game of hockey. She realises Sadness' true purpose- To alert others when Riley needs a helping hand. Joy finds Bing Bong's song-powered rocket, and she eventually finds her way back to HeadQuarters with Sadness, only to find that the other emotions instilled the idea to run away to Minnesota to restore happy core memories. All of her personality islands have collapsed and the console had locked up, rendering Riley apathetic.Sadness is the only one who can remove the idea, and she takes control of the console, restoring control and causing Riley to return to her parents.Overall, Inside Out is one of the finest pictures to come out of Pixar, It will make you laugh, it will jerk tears even from the toughest of folk, it has a rock-solid storyline and a realistic, but charming animation style- using particles rather that skin-and-bone 3D animation for the emotions and a cold, steely look for San Francisco. It conveys its message in an ingenious, fun and a very relatable way. Inside Out may be classed as family film, but there is a lot of quite complex concepts such as depression, apathy, personality, running away, and memory, things that young kids simply can't understand, however, this film will please adults, teenagers and Pixar fans alike. This is definitely a film worthy to be called an instant classic and I guarantee that this film will make you think, and question "What is going on inside their head?"*

I have never written a review but after reading some of the negative reviews of this movie I had to speak up. Inside Out manages to entertain and educate from young to old on multiple levels. The five basic human emotions, well known to practicing therapists or anyone studying psychology, become living characters. They take part in a story that the viewer can easily relate to and enjoy. As expected from Pixar the animation is fantastic and the background score fits perfectly.This movie should be a first week requirement for Psych 101 in any college yet, my 4 year old granddaughter loves it, watches it repeatedly and understands the basic concepts. I recently sat her on my lap and asked her what were the 5 basic human emotions. She quickly listed the emotions and reminded me, "Papa, you can't have joy without sadness." When you can entertain and educate a 4 year old and a 67 year old, make them laugh and cry together, and make them want to watch again and again you've really done something special. Thank you Pixar. And, to all those negative reviewers remember, "You can't have joy without sadness."

This film was a story of 5 emotions inside a girl named Riley: Joy, Sad, Anger, Disgust, Fear. One day, Joy and Sad were lost, out of the controlling room. And they must find the way to come back before something was too late... Well,the film was so funny and interesting. Pixar created 5 emotions with 5 different colors and pictures. All of them were different and so cute. And Bing Bong, a creature created by Riley's imagination, were so cute too. And the journey of Joy, Sad and Bing Bong were interesting too. Following it, we realize many things around us that sometimes we forget: our family, our friend, beautiful life, our passion, our imagination.... Sometimes, the film made us be moved to tears... and sometimes, it made us smile... Very impressive And above all, there was a message from this film: "Family were the best" This was a good film for all of us, me and you and everyone.
Another spiritual journey by Pixar. Woww. I see some reviews simply barking without a clue

reviews.review_title: Hands down one of the BEST movies I've seen in a LONG time!
reviews.content: When my 4-year-old son begged me to take him to see this movie, I was bracing myself for another round of animation with mindless slapstick comedy for kids and a few one-liners geared towards the parents. Boy, was I surprised!Inside Out was a poignant and touching story, and the movie had layers upon layers of lessons and meaning carefully and masterfully crafted into witty dialogue. There were no gratuitous musical numbers, no endless comedic sequences that make you giggle but don't progress the story, and yet the movie was well-paced, well-written, and thoroughly enjoyable from start to finish.This story truly had something for everyone - the kids in the theater all giggled, the adults sniffled and sighed, and I can think of quite a few former teachers of mine who would have gleefully screened this movie to provide fodder for debate for weeks worth of lessons. Most importantly to me, all of the members of our family left the theater raving about what we had just seen- that never happens... ever. For the first time in years, I felt as if we really got our money's worth when we left a movie. Inside Out is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

Took my 11 year old and 6 year old girls to see this film at the drive-in last night. First off the movie was long, wouldn't of seen at the drive- in if I had known! I didn't get home until midnight and the drive-in only showed the minion movie preview beforehand. My girls seemed bored in many spots. Only got a few laughs and maybe 1 or 2 quotable lines from the film. Creative yes, but my kids didn't get into a lot of the stuff in the film. The cartoon before the movie is great for preschool kids. My youngest just finished kindergarten and she wasn't into it. Seemed very Dora like. Save your money and wait for DVD or when it is on pay per view. In the meantime, just take them to the new minion movie. It is really what all kids are waiting to see and some of us parents!

reviews.review_title: Best animated movie of all time.
reviews.content: Fantastic story line. Emotional film. Awesome characters development. This movie is just perfect.

reviews.review_title: A must see for people of all ages
reviews.content: I understand that some people may find this film to be quite dark and 'not for the kids', but I think what people fail to understand is that, despite it being animated, this isn't technically a kids film. What I find it to be is a cinematic masterpiece, reaching new highs in Pixar animation and doing it so well. It made me feel sad, happy and pretty much every emotion in between. What I also love about this film is that it's one of the first modern animated films to really dig below the surface of how it feels to face difficult mental states, such as depression, which many people, including myself, can really relate to. Fantastic film, would definitely recommend at least a watch!

One of the best animated movies ever made.
Emotionally touching and will bring back your memories from every situation you have been through as a kid and teenager.

reviews.review_title: Inventive, Gorgeous, Oh! Remember to bring some Tissues.
reviews.content: Inside out is a different, amazingly animated and an other heart touching addition to Pixar library of modern animated classics. Narrated from the emotional side of 'emotions' inside an eleven year old's head, the plot has many carefully planted moments of tension where your heart would definitely skip a beat. Be it falling bridges or endless pits your are sure to let out a gasp and feel for them, feelings. Parents are likely to get hit the hardest, I would suggest you bring some tissues. Like Toy Story its a story about leaving your childhood behind. Inside out manages the delicate feat of being worldly wise without sacrificing your sense of innocence. Riley may be on the cusp of adolescence but the button of Puberty is never pressed. This makes it even more interesting as we are left to think, if emotions could cause so much stir in children, then what about teens? Think about all the mood swings they go through!What hasn't changed in all the family movies is the notion that 'there is no place like home'. This notion is played with differently in different movies. For Riley and her emotions it is togetherness, if you with your mum and dad then you can keep world at a bay. Although most of the content is appropriate for elementary schoolers and up, younger kids may need a bit more explanation about what's going on, since there are references to abstract thought and the subconscious, and it can be a little confusing when other characters' emotions are shown.Overall the level of invention is so high, and the density of detail is so great, that it's impossible to absorb everything in a single viewing. Kids and their parents, psychologists and philosophers alike, are all bound to be awed by Pixar's latest and boldest feature yet. It is the universality of the film that makes it an instant classic.Let me sum it up like this, how do you make a movie good? Just take something inanimate, give it some feelings, some emotion and a dash of dealings with the unconscious, the spectrum of Freud, voilà you are now watching one of Pixar's masterpieces. Push it bit further and give the emotion itself an emotion, think about how feelings would feel and you end up with an all time best, Inside out.
This animation is based on a great idea, but i was disapointed about the screenplay

How the feelings feels concept take this film to the one of the bests from Pixar. Not only the main characters are interesting but also the others too, for example the imaginary friend. The animation is excellent. The character interactions is brilliant. All the time when Joy talk to sadness. The voice acing is amazing. The story can be too smart for a child, but as I know, they can enjoy this movie. Not as much as the older people, everyone can learn something. From the beginning until the end entertaining,sensible, emotional. And the ending jokes...I recommend for everyone!(please somebody give the "best animated movie Oscar" to the creators!!)

reviews.review_title: The first half was a bit slow, but the second half was brilliantly funny.
reviews.content: The first half was a bit slow, but the second half was brilliantly funny.
Inside Out is a captivating film that I would describe as a Cinematic Masterpiece. Everyone should watch this.

This film (in addition to the book "Leaf by Niggle" written by J.R.R. Tolkien) gave me the idea to imagine my thoughts as separate aspects of my whole personality.I find that this process (breaking emotions down into separate/manageable aspects or "voices") helps in dealing with emotional hangups & in making decisions without them.To help the reader understand... say I have an argument with a lover. Words of anger are exchanged. I can apologize right away and ask for some time to think. When alone I can talk it out in my head. One voice can be "anger" & it will say all the things that made it upset. One voice can be "love" (my favorite) and it will maybe validate anger in it's feelings YET it will also present the facts in a different light, a perspective not consumed with emotional distress but instead focused on the goal of loving. Maybe a third voice will be objective ("robot"?) and view all the facts and present solutions coming from a base line of who I am as a person and what I really want. Solutions being, how to fix the emotional distress (apologize sincerely?) and present preventative measures to take to avoid troubles of this nature in the future.I am no psychologist but I know that this helps me to be a more balanced (not more happy/sad/angry) person.Feelsgoodman ^-^

reviews.review_title: This movie was special to me
reviews.content: For me, this cartoon is one of those cartoons worth watching in life. Since I'm not a kid any more, but something has remained in my mind since that time, that is why this movie was special to me.

reviews.review_title: Pixar, you really pushed my emotions
reviews.content: I've always loved Pixar movies and I consider "Up" to be my favorite movie of ALL TIME. I had high hopes for "Inside Out", as I always do for Pixar films, and I don't know if it met them. "Inside Out" is a movie which I believe everyone can relate to in some sense or another. But it's not what I expect from a Pixar movie. I expect Pixar movies to have that deep moral and theme but also to be light on you and full with great jokes, but the moral and them of "Inside Out" felt too deep and the jokes were meager and not the jokes I expected. I tend to laugh at every little joke and I didn't laugh too much. Granted, there were times I did laugh way too hard but those were well deserved. However, the rest of the movie was very serious and did keep me on the edge of my seat. I've seen plenty of dramas about growing up that weren't this deep or depressing that were obviously made for an older crowd. If you want a light-hearted, fun Pixar adventure, this is not the one to see; I'd suggest "The Good Dinosaur" coming this fall. I honestly felt like this Pixar film was going after the wrong demographic because young kids would not understand the movie. I would recommend this movie for kids 12 and up because most likely your kid will not understand. Now this movie was excellently made and was a joy to watch; pun intended. However, you will need to be ready to cry because that is just what this film will do to you. I didn't walk out of the theater filling happy but more depressed and had a heavy feeling that it had made upon my thoughts. I honestly still feel like I didn't fully captivate the whole depth it had emotionally wise and I am planning on seeing another screening of it. That being said, it's not a complex story but I need to fully form my opinions about it. If your emotions to be pushed to their maximum, see this movie. This is a really well made movie that looks incredible with a well developed story. It deserves the Pixar badge it has attached to its name and won't let you down.

reviews.review_title: One of the most real movies in a long time
reviews.content: I love this movie. Anyone in touch with themselves will feel how real and accurate Inside Out is, and that's why it's refreshing. It's not something that's been recreated over and over and over again. It's not a dumb, mindless movie. The storyline, characters, and setting was extremely relatable for me (and I would assume a lot of kids/people) and that's what pulls you in. There's hilarious jokes throughout, and sad moments which balance the movie. I know a lot of bad reviews were because they thought it was "too scary" or "too complex" for kids, but I don't think it's any different than movies I grew up with in the 90s. Snow White and The Brave Little Toaster has scary animations, and there's plenty of super sad moments in older movies (and recent Pixar movies), like The Lion King. The difference with Inside Out is that it depicts those emotions in a relatable way, through an 11-year old dealing with situations a lot of kids have dealt with. It shows how complex they can be, and creates a simplified way of looking at yourself, how it all works in your brain, so it doesn't feel as overwhelming or scary. I think the happy ending was necessary, because you don't want to show kids that feelings of sadness or fear lead something bad and that's it. You want to show them that it's normal, and it gets better. I personally think this should be a requirement for everyone to watch, you'll laugh and cry and feel like a human being again.

reviews.review_title: Lovely realistic movie that pulls at your heart strings.
reviews.content: I personally had just watched this movie recently after hearing many good things about it. I was interested in it because it deals with emotions and I am very interested in the psychology of the mind. Let me start by stating that I am not a die hard Disney or pixar fan, Im not one to sit down and watch a cartoon movie but was compelled to this one so I sat and I watched, what ensued was emotion. I laughed, a cried, I felt. This movie from the perspective of an 11 year old girl who is torn away from her friends, school and hockey team. I am imagine this is how she would feel because I too at one point was an 11 year old girl who was forced into foster care and torn away from friends, family and everything I knew. I can feel for Riley, I remember going to a new school for the first time and feeling scared, nervous and absolutely terrified. Crying in front of a whole class! Holy crap that would be mortifying and I have done it too and it is mortifying, I've eaten by myself in a corner. I also ran away from home although I wasn't as young as Riley. I loved that Pixar depicted such a loving, happy home because I didn't have that growing up, seeing this helped me to see what normal looks like and to many kids out there who don't come from non dysfunctional families I think this might show them what a happy, healthy home can look like. This movie tugged at my heart strings both because Riley had the home and parents I did not and also because I was so happy that she did, I know its a kids movie but I think it goes much deeper, I cant imagine Im the only one who felt so deeply and moved watching this. I also commend the makers for making this movie I think it will help many adults and children who struggle with emotions. Seeing that sadness is needed and not a waste of time. We can't bury our emotions and all of them mean something even the not so great ones. It was awesome to see empathy modeled when Sadness listen to Bing Bong. It was heart warming that Joy wanted so desperately to return to her rightful place. Coming from someone who has struggled with depression, wow! That struggle of joy being lost and needing to get back to its right place is so real. Showing that rightfully our true state is happiness and joy is so comforting. This is more a PSA than a regular ole Pixar movie. This should be shown to all kids when they are young and then talked about with them after. I loved so much that the movie ended on a happy note with Riley coming home to her parents and not being shamed or yelled at but being held and comforted. It was perfect parent modeling. After it shows it fast forwarded a bit where Riley is now on a new hockey team and she is embarrassed that her parents are making such a big deal, they love her so much and it shows, they are so supportive. Riley then bumps into a boy and it shows inside his head that everything is going crazy because a girl just talked to him. Haha! I can relate man..wow. I wish there was more and so I could see how Riley grows up. Such an awesome movie.

reviews.review_title: Inside Out -The little voise inside your head (Movie Review)
reviews.content:
Today, I'm going to review the 2015 Walt Disney and Pixar's "Inside Out". It is an animated movie about emotions and family problems. But more about that later! I have already seen this movie before, like 5 times, so watching it the sixth time, is not so fun anymore, but still, it have very good sides, but also some bad sides.The story is set in present day, in Minnesota. Riley is a happy girl that lives with her family. The feelings inside her head (Joy, Sadness, Anger, Disgust and Fear) is also showed as "persons" or "talking things". It is showed in a cool way how the feelings are talking to each other and they also show the "Switchboard" where the feelings are stearing Riley's emotions. Riley's head is showed as a country with "Dreamland" or other stuff that it is in Riley's head. Everything seems good until Riley's parents decide to move to San Francisco and her life turns on the head.My favourite voice-actor from the movie is Joy (Amy Poehler). Amy had a good voice to this character and I think she did a good job with her expression and intonation. The rest of the voice-actors was ok, but pretty generic.What I liked in "Inside Out" was the music (By Michael Giocchino). The Music was quiet nice and I liked the tunes and I really liked it. I also liked the consept that the feelings was showed as "people" or "talking things", and I think children will like this. What I didn't like is that It's getting boring in the end because it is not so interesting, and after watching it the sixth time, my opinion about this movie is getting lower.What I learned from this movie is that it is important to show and share your feelings with others and that friendship and family is the most important in your life (Like I didn't knew that before *Sarcasm*).I recommend this movie for children for the age 5-9 years old and for people who like Disney movies. Or you can even just watch this movie if you haven't seen it before.Rating:
My overall rating for "Inside Out" is (5/10).PS: I think this movie is not so rememberble. That's why I forgot to rate this movie on my app.

reviews.review_title: Not Pixar's Best but Highly Original
reviews.content: I watched this for a second time the other day. From a visual perspective, this is one of the least beautiful Pixar creations. Look at the poster. In my opinion there is a an all around lack of taste and style. That said, this is an amazingly out of the box and high concept story which is very well told. Leave it to Pixar to make something this weird and experimental into a thoroughly enjoyable and relatable piece of mass entertainment for all ages. If this was made by an other studio, I might give this a 9 instead of a 8. But my standards for Pixar are crazy high. That is not fair I guess but at least I am being honest about it :)

reviews.review_title: A very intelligent and original movie
reviews.content: Pixar is back on track with this one their best work since Toy Story 3. Inside out is a very original movie that younger kids are going to enjoy because of the beautiful animation and the funny characters and older kids and adults will appreciate the very mature themes and ideas that this movie present. I don't want to say a lot about the movie because I did not know anything about the movie before watching it except for the general idea that you follow a young girl named Riley and you see how her emotions works and how they deals with all the changes that happens in Riley's life. I am not going to say a lot more about this movie because I think that the fact that I didn't know a lot about the movie made me appreciate the originality of this movie and the ideas that it shows even more. I am also very happy to see a kids movie that is intelligent and that threats kids like intelligent people and not only try to make them laughs with cheap jokes like a lot of kids movies. Finally, don't think this movie is only for kids like a lot of Pixar movies there are tons of jokes for adults, I also think it will make any adults think about their childhood and all the things we let go in order to become an adult and the moral of the movie is a strong one that challenges some of the conceptions that we have in our society today about our emotions.The only downside I have about this movie doesn't even comes from me but from my friends who saw the movie with me and loved it too but he thoughts that it could have benefit from more exciting action scenes. I didn't fell that way when I watched the movie but I can still see how some people would like the movie even more with those kinds of scenes. Sorry for my English it's not my native language hopefully you were still able to understand my thoughts and impressions about this movie.

reviews.review_title: Great idea, degraded by a not-so-great execution.
reviews.content: Inside-Out is a good movie, that could've been great! The idea is spectacular and original, the characters and their personalities were perfect. The plot was unique and had a great potential in the first 45 minutes. After that, it starts to take the highway of an ordinary animation movie that isn't so bad for usual animations, but not for this one. They could've done many more things to execute this brilliant idea properly. They could've worked on Riley's adventure more in running away, rather than spending all the movie on the feelings' adventures, for example. All in all, it's an entertaining movie, but again, could've been great!

The best Pixar movie at the time, teaches us that happiness not only depends on joy, sadness is also necessary to be happy, regarding the development of Riley's emotions, joy stopped being authoritarian with sadness so that Riley can experience it shows us what a teenager is like when he is growing up, and he experiences new emotions in his life, the representation in the emotions of his parents was very clear, apparently anger dominates him, and the mother sadness, the movie accompanies her a beautiful aesthetic making us feel emotions when we see it, I would like to go see it at the cinema againI would like to go see it at the cinema again.

Inside Out is a masterpiece. It's the first movie this year to really blow me away, and I haven't been able to stop thinking about it. It really is worthy of all the hype surrounding it, and that's saying a lot.This movie's writing and execution is clever and fantastic. They managed to explain the simple and everyday things and thoughts that cross our minds brilliantly with just the right amount of comedy and heart. Never has a movie made me think "That makes so much sense!" quite so often, all the while making me laugh harder than any movie I've seen in a long time, and also making me emotional for its beautiful elements and moments. Inside Out is an absolute delight, and I honestly can't wait to watch it again.Both adults and kids will most likely enjoy this movie, even if some of the elements might go over some kids' heads. Personally, I think everyone should see it. It's a fantastic film, and the 94-minute runtime just flew by me. I highly recommend it.

One of my fav movies , its so inspiring in terms of knowing how emotions workout inside our head ,how childhood affects our life when we are kids . Its not just an animation movie its a whole system of how our memories and how childhood memories can cause breakdowns , every time I feel sad or angry this movie pops in my heads , I actually started naming my emotions like characters and helped me a lot in my own mental health , so its actually more than just a movie , its scan to our subconscious a closer look of how mind works . I hope more movies are done like that to help us deal with emotions.

reviews.review_title: A very imaginative and interesting movie
reviews.content: In a time when Hollywood mindlessly churns out reboots and remakes, Inside Out stands alone in its sheer originality and inventiveness. Inside Out is one of the most intelligent ideas Pixar (or any filmmaker for that matter) has ever put to screen, and possibly their most accessible film to date. Even when I felt some individual characters in the film begin to cloy, that feeling quickly dissipated, as I was soon blind-sided by their charm only seconds later. As with the universally acclaimed Toy Story 3, Inside Out clips along at a relatively fast pace, but never feels hollow, and is often hilarious throughout. Every moment of this film is truly a joy (no pun intended) to behold. Also read full reviews here http://inside-out-watch.blogspot.com

This movie is totally a 10 (or 9 or 8) and if you say otherwise is because you totally missed the point. I can't express how much this movie helped me through depression (among other things). Absolutely loved it!

Inside out is a sweet and interesting film which starts with a new life coming and finishes with more life, really colorful and funny, with very good jokes and not tacky at all. Everybody said about the scientific things in the film, I cant deny, that is terrific, but what make it awesome is the way it is treated. With a lot of colors and delicate movements pixar made a scientific film that has an emotional part working together very well, the characters are convincing as they can, showing emotional complexity (even the emotions characters) and being touching for the public of all ages. The screenplay is perfect, with a lot of explanations about how your brain work and it never becomes boring, I don't have words to describe the direction, and the soundtrack is, like every other Pixar film, pleasantly incredible (the theme is very cute and addictive). If someone ask me to describe this film in one word, my answer would be: Creativity.
It has all the feels of a Disney film as can be expected. But I'm taking down a point just because I personally don't appreciate the look of the characters.

This movie was by far the funniest in some aspects, but not all the way. Yes there was some serious parts like Running away from home won't solve your problems and a ton of other meanings. Basically Joy and Sadness embark on an amazing adventure after something dreadful happens to the core memories.While Anger, Disgust, and Fear are trying to keep Rileys emotions up it turns from bad to worse, Riley starts stealing and then runs off trying to get back home all to find out that maybe life isn't so bad where she lived. The funniest parts were with Bing Bong and the singing/musical wagon which I really loved, and SPOILER ALERT....WHEN BINGBONG GETS FORGOTTEN I CRIED LIKE TEARS AND ALL.This movie is a good family movie, even though it doesn't show all of our emotions and just the main ones, I thoroughly enjoyed it and I know your family or friends will love it as well

I think this movie will know be among the best that Pixar has done and I think you are asking: is this film at that level: Monsters.inc, Toy Story, Ratatouille, Finding Nemo, etc. Pixar have made one of the best companies in terms of animation. yes, if it's a great movie, if an interesting plot, has good history, scenery and colorful characters and a great climax that make this film a masterpiece, I personally lying if I said I did not cry and excited with Inside-Out with especially the scene in which Bing-Bong sacrifices to Joy could save Riley and the scene in which Joy realizes the importance of Sadness. I truly believe that when we look into the future to the past and think in 2015 immediately remember those sweet and colorful scenes in addition to the hilarious physical comedy scenes of Fear, which reminds me of Matt Smith's role in the television series Doctor Who besides that scene in which deceives Anger Disgust using it to melt and leaving the window Joy and Sadness enter the headquarters. Personally I think this film came easily to the 2nd or 3rd 1st place of the top five Pixar Movies faithfully as I think it's great, grand, sweet and full of emotion.

reviews.review_title: Afilm exploring feelings through a little girls eyes and how they play a big part in our lives
reviews.content: A fantastic film full of fantastic ideas and creatively put together. i loved the opening scene with the two volcanoes that were looking for love , i found it very funny but also at moments quite sad. This in my opinion helps show the message of the film that you cant have happiness without sadness. as , as you look back on it you'll find yourself smiling but also feeling sad.Due to the fact that the volcanoes nearly didn't find each other. as the film its self started i thought it started of a little bit slow but once it got started there was no stopping it.I thoroughly enjoyed it and laughed almost all the time. very creative ideas that were put together to create this brilliant film

Pixar, the studio which brought us some of the overly cute and striking films of recent times like Toy Story, Finding Nemo, Monsters Inc, Shrek - to name a few, is back with another cinematic delight - Inside Out. The studio lives up to its reputation of presenting brilliantly scripted stories via amazing animations by delivering a film which rattles the existing notions of emotions and feelings.The main characters of the movie are its five personified emotions- Joy (Amy Poehler), Sadness (Phyllis Smith), Fear (Bill Hader), Anger (Lewis Black), and Disgust (Mindy Kaling)- each capturing the essence of their respective name. The story revolves around a teenage girl, Riley (Kaitlyn Dias) and it depicts how her emotions make all the decisions of her life and help her cope with her problems.As the plot develops, we witness complex interactions among these emotions and other elements of the mind, like dreams, thoughts and memories. Various events taking place in Riley's life are explored with respect to their connection with her emotions. The movie is an emotional roller-coaster, with some really poignant scenes interspersed with light-hearted moments.As is expected from a Pixar movie, Inside Out pushes the boundaries of computer generated imagery and animation to give us an unforgettable experience. The soundtrack binds the story together wonderfully. In my opinion, the movie is an absolute treat for the senses and I recommend it as a must watch.

reviews.review_title: The new Pixar movie is amazing !
reviews.content: This new Pixar movie will make you laugh, cry, and think...It's a complete masterpiece about people's thoughts and emotions.those things you have to forget when you grow up.If you like the best Pixar movies (Up, the Toy Story trilogy) you'll have to love this one. Reviews are great all around the world. I actually saw people cry in the audience.It's so clever it will charm children and adults alike. There's a whole reflexion on what's going on in a little girl's mind, and I loved the movie so much I've made a video analysis of it: http://marlasmovies.blogspot.fr/2015/06/inside-out-where-is-my- mind.html

I've watched this movie a couple times now and I have loved it each time. I think some people are really missing the point of the movie: it's okay to be sad sometimes and you cannot force happiness. Joy is a very annoying character at times but she is meant to be (at times). I think everyone (including younger kids and adults) can learn that it actually is okay not to be okay, and this funny and clever movie is a great way to learn it.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant movie for the whole family!
reviews.content: This was a great film to watch with young kids. I was surrounded by kids ranging from 3 to 13, including myself (the eternal child). Interesting on how the different ages reacted and connected to the characters in the movie. It was a great way for the older kids to see their emotions (any emotion) being validated and expressed visually. It is a great movie for the whole family.

Refreshingly original concept for a movie! Well done, Pixar, for teaching kids about emotions. If only all adults were not afraid to access, understand and appreciate their feelings rather than stuffing them down, the world would be a healthier place (search "metaphysical reasons for illnesses".I would have loved to see a few more advanced emotions, rather than Joy handling it all, such as hope, safety and security (search "list of feelings nvc"). It would also have been nice to show how the thoughts train actually generates our emotional state; however, I understand that it was a children's film. Anyway, it was like having a basic map of how our feelings work in conjunction with each other, as well as with other parts of the mind (and heart).

This film tells about how we feel when we are angry, sad, happy and other feelings.
the presentation is also very interesting and not boring, for me this film is very creative where it can be thought to make a story about how a feeling is created in a visual form.

I'm not sure if I'm the only one, but anyone who suffers with mental illness may have 'blackened or phased out' emotions.Watching this film and actually sitting through it allows you to realise that those emotions are still there and gets you to focus on them more.In my opinion a fun film with a realistic outlook of the mind. Not only this, but the kids do not budge throughout the whole film.

reviews.review_title: A visual and emotional spectacle to behold!
reviews.content: Pixar does it once again! This movie marked the start of what I have dubbed the Pixar Emotional Renaissance which feature not only this, but Coco and Toy Story 4. The lighting of everything is amazing, from the soft glow that Joy emits to the heat waves above Anger's head when he gets "fired up" Fear is the best character and it's helped by Bill Hader being an amazing actor. You'll laugh and you'll cry. All in all, this is a wonderful movie
I really liked it. Recommend. Love it. itrs very interesting and there are some funny lines in this movie.

I really didn't enjoy this movie. Im not entirely sure why but there are several factors that come to my mind after watching the film. Firstly, the animation choice is definitely very different from normal Pixar films, it threw me right off. Secondly, the story and pacing of the film was really slow and not much going on. I could definitely see children being bored of this movie almost instantaneously, it has way too many adult themes throughout the movie. I dont think I could ever re-watch this movie, knowing how I felt after seeing it for the first time. It just felt like the heart and soul of the movie was missing.

First off, I really enjoyed this film - it's fun, imaginative and clever (and fortunately much better than its sister short 'Lava'). Despite what I say next, I would still recommend watching.However something was missing from the overall mix. The film begins with a lot of promise - in a few short minutes, the overall scenario is established quickly without swamping you in the technical details of 'Headquarters' and there's clear potential in the set-up: Riley, an eleven year old girl approaching the hinterland between childhood and adolescence, is leaving her old life behind and moving to a new and unfamiliar town.Unfortunately the plot then starts to meander. Ironically, the biggest casualty of this is Riley herself, whose character and interaction with the real world is quickly lost within the narrative. Aside from her first day at school and a half-baked plot involving her escape from home, she is strangely underused as a character in her own right. It would have been fascinating to see her make new friends and to navigate the pressures of school and a new life in a new city.Instead, the plot is centred on two primary emotions navigating the unstable terrain between various 'islands' at the back of her brain, assisted by Riley's long forgotten imaginary friend Bing-Bong. Whilst it's a fun plot that, by and large, works well on its own merits, it feels like the product of Disney's heavy hand instead of Pixar's acclaimed nuance. The elephant was, in my opinion, a mistake. There is no present and apparent connection between Riley and Bing-Bong and so the character's metaphorical role in representing Riley's transition to adolescence falls flat. While Andy's separation from Woody and Buzz worked so brilliantly in Toy Story, Riley's separation from Bing-Bong felt... meh. As soon as Joy and Bing-Bong fell into the chasm, it was pretty clear what was going to happen next.And so the film grinds to a saccharine and predicable conclusion: Joy and Sadness work together in harmony, Riley gets off the bus and returns home and all is well and good again in Headquarters. Great, I loved it, but I can't help but feel that there's a far stronger version of this film somewhere on the writing room floor. A version that manages to successfully combine the real world with the events transpiring in Riley's head, a version where the emotions themselves are more complex figures, and a version that serves as a more confident meditation on the end of childhood.It's a great film, but unfortunately it falls short of the high standards set during Pixar's 'Golden Era'. --- Having said all this, I probably should highlight some of the positives for balance.The animation is nothing short of excellent. The voice acting is also great. I loved the brief forays into other people's Headquarters. The dream studio scenes were fantastic. The whole film was much better than Lava! Joy and Sadness were brilliantly crafted as characters, if a little one-dimensional at times.

reviews.review_title: A wonderful adventure where Riley's emotions, masters of everyday life, face challenges that affect her coming of age after her parents uproot her.
reviews.content: "Inside out" is, in my humble opinion the best movie Pixar has ever made. As an animation studio, they have managed to set themselves apart with beautiful heartfelt stories that continue down the line of Walt Disney's masterpieces.Here we see five predominant emotions: Joy, Sadness, Fear, Disgust and Anger, as characters inside a little girl's head. From her birth, we follow the emotions on how they make us do what we do. Get mad, laugh, cry, even how we dream. Every single aspect of our mind is depicted in colorful well thought of places and characters. From the "subconcious prison" to "imagination land"; light bulbs to plug in for ideas, memories getting stored in shelves or even the train of thought that runs through our heads."Inside out" has achieved everything. It is both an adventure and a coming of age story where the humans are not as close to us as the little people inside our head are, but they are still so real. The movie will make you feel both nostalgia and joy as you watch your emotions and memories pass by on the screen. It's about acceptance, and makes us see sense in how we evolve towards adulthood.Here, your mind is a town full of complex mechanisms that somehow make sense if we picture it inside our heads. Pixar has made another masterpiece, but this time it isn't it's characters or its story you will remember, it's the universe and its morality, the great lesson you take into account about your emotions and yourself. You will laugh, cry and feel as if no other film or cartoon has ever showed who we are and how we work as humans better than "Inside out". One you have seen it, you will no doubt carry on with your daily life imagining your emotions running around inside your head.

reviews.review_title: Strong connection to 1972 Inside/Out series of short films.
reviews.content: See "Inside/Out" at Wikipedia. I used the Inside/Out series of 15m shorts in 16mm reel to reel format as a teaching tool for my sixth grade students in 1975/76. It was a public produced, teacher led class discussion focused, aid to young people to help them explore how to handle their emotions in a variety of realistic social situations. I am astonished that I have yet to find the 2015 movie providing any acknowledgment to "Inside/Out"!I wonder how many stupid extraneous fill in words i will be allowed to write in my attempt to accomplish the IMDb requirement that this review be lengthy enough to fill ten lines of text?

Inside Out is an outstandingly original, heartfelt story from Pixar about growing up and learning to handle your biggest emotions. Told primarily from the perspective of the feelings inside 11-year-old Riley's mind the plot has many moments including bridges/islands crumbling, a train tumbling over a precipice, and characters falling into a deep, dark pit. Some of Riley's fears are also on display, including a giant, scary clown. Parents are likely to get hit hardest by the film's heart-tugging moments, but anyone with empathy will feel for Riley as she experiences life's ups and downs. Ultimately, Inside Out has important messages about needing to feel and express all of your emotions, whether happy or sad. Although most of the content is appropriate for elementary schoolers and up, younger kids may need a bit more explanation about what's going on, since there are references to abstract thought and the subconscious, and it can be a little confusing when other characters emotions are shown.
''Emotions'' is the perfect word to use to describe this amazing masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: I don't understand the other reviews...
reviews.content:
Hi..., my name is Joy and I'm in the rightful way to answer all of your questions.
Frankly, I don't see the problem with our movie. Even so, it's a family one, but made up for the enjoy of the grown-ups. Maybe you hate it because all of the shouting of Fury, but he can't help it...Inside Out IT'S NOT the biggest Pixar mistakes, (have you seen the ones that Cars made?) but honestly, it's a movie for reflection and understanding our minds. You have to admit it, trying to explain what's is happening inside your heads isn't an easy task. Totally the opposite. Riley is just a girl that it's trying to live her continuos changes that are occurring in her life. Familie, school, friends, even the first tastes of partnership love; that's something difficult to put on in the big screen. I don't blame you, maybe you are happy with the movies that have a hero and a villain. That's how Hollywood has been making all of these years. Maybe you feel comfortable with the idea of seeing the end of the plot since the beginning of the movie. With my friends, well, we tried to perform how did Riley's mind work. Of course it's not the brain of an important guy, or a big president, whatever. But, our animators, creatives, and designers work too freaking hard for trying to imagine how does a simple girl brain do work. You even saw an ally die in this animated movie, come on!, didn't you cry with the tragic death of Riley's imaginary friend?, dudes you really have stone hearts.I must admit that there are little troubles with the making of the rules of some parts of Riley's brain. But you have to take in mind that human brain is an unexplored field nowadays. But well, I f you don't enjoy our movie, don't be too hard with us. However, you have at least to clap and be amazed with the special effects that we have. The music, the incredible designs of our characters, come on!, they are great!From more than 50 different emotions, only have to choose 5?!, that's another problem. What you don't have in mind also, is that the movie would at least last 4 or 3 hours with all of those other emotions. In fact, it could be a total cinematographic mess that our directors wouldn't had approved. Sorry guys, but I repeat, understanding human mind is something too hard in this years.Joy, out!

reviews.review_title: A thought provoking movie for both kids and adults!
reviews.content: Pixar, you've done it again! This is an incredibly well thought out movie that is enjoyable for the whole family. It is captivating from start to finish. It is a great take on what goes on in ones head, from what we say, think and feel, what we remember, how we interact with our surroundings as well as differentiating facts from opinions. It delves into how one can also stop feeling when they're going through the darkest of times. So cleverly done, with both humour and serious scenes that keep you on the edge of your seat. Not to mention, scenes that give you the feels. This is a movie that evokes all kinds of emotions no matter how old you are. It highlights the importance of family, friends and all sorts of other important things in our lives that make us who we are. And as usual, it teaches us so many life lessons that... well ... one would not expect a kids movie to teach us all. Absolutely fantastic!

Okay, I could talk about this movie all day - but for brevity's sake I'll try to use this review to address just two key observations. To begin with, this is the first IMDB review that I've felt compelled to write - and compelled is the appropriate word - as the many poorly formulated critiques of this offering demand a robust rebuttal.Firstly, in answer to those individuals who feel that this wonderfully imaginative romp was in any way simplistic - sadly they have neither the intellectual sophistication to appreciate the insights it offers to adults nor the bountiful enthusiasm to recognise the wonder it serves up for wee ones. To suggest that this is some sort of half-baked telling in which a bit of a cry rights the world's ills is, in and of itself, an extraordinarily over-simplistic analysis of the narrative. On the contrary - the whole point of the story is that Riley (by means of her personified emotions) must journey inside herself, consult her dreams and explore the recesses of her subconscious mind in order to learn to embrace her negative emotions - so that she may become a more integrated and well-rounded individual capable of dealing with life's many challenges. This is the crux of psychoanalytic thought - one of the most important and valuable contributions thinkers have made to our collective understanding of the human condition - and this film artfully communicates it in language that children can understand.Secondly, the notion that this is too sad or depressing for children is actually quite infantile. Kids are not idiots or one-dimensional beings that need to be shielded from the harsh realities of life. In fact, anyone who has a rudimentary understanding of child psychology would know that attempting to achieve this generally results in significant damage to their mental health. There's more than enough accessible comedy contained within this animated masterpiece to keep the tone light and fun - but for the record, the film's that spoke to me most powerfully as a child (namely the animated version of The Lord of the Rings, Watership Down, The Never-ending Story and Return of the Jedi) all contained darkness aplenty.I'm genuinely concerned for the futures of the children of parents who were unsettled by the tone of this marvellous effort. Please watch it - the somewhat grumbly tone of this review might detract from the glittering gems it has to offer - but trust me, it's hilarious, delightful and ultimately extremely uplifting.

It is good animation, and it has its moments, but it is just too unhealthy, unrealistic, and nonsensical in how the emotions interact, and in how they put together Riley's arc. The loss of memories just did not quite make sense. She may not view them the same, but she does not have Alzheimer's, so the crisis, and the tragic part of the movie lost a lot of their sting for me due to their relatively weak reasons for happening. So while it was not bad, its story construction was weak, and it was not for me. I know a lot of people who use the excuse it is animation to excuse these types of shortcomings, and they generally enjoyed this movie more than me, so it may still be worth the watch.

The cartoon has five fat pluses. First, the detailing of small things. For example, I was most struck by the hair, namely the fact that every hair on the head is drawn. Secondly, an excellent gamma, which has very rich colors that please the eye, and the dynamics of the change in warmth gives the scenes an additional atmosphere. Thirdly, the authors were able to show Riley's feelings so naturally that I sincerely worried about her fate. Fourthly, an excellent gamma, which has very rich colors that please the eye, and the dynamics of the change in warmth gives the scenes an additional atmosphere. It also has its own: motion animation, shadow and highlight. In the cartoon, you can see it very well. Fifthly, a unique concept presented by the personification of human emotions to real personalities. And the sixth, of course, is an interesting story that makes you carefully follow what is happening on the screen, waiting for further events.

reviews.review_title: Crying and Laughing at the Same Time
reviews.content: This movie had me feeling two emotions at the same time. The scene that stood out to me is from when Bing Bong and Joy sings a song to fly the rocket, and then Bing Bong decided to leave himself behind. I'm disappointed in this movie because it was bloated with too many ideas and the story wasn't polished in the least. In building their universe they quickly introduced concepts with no explanation at all and some of those ideas were out of place because they didn't fit the theme, which this movie actually lacked. There wasn't a focal point because everything was watered down. Things seemed to be done arbitrarily. I did expect more substance and refinement from players like Disney/Pixar, even for a kid's movie, which this totally is. I have to chalk this one up to laziness. Amazing potential, but mediocre execution.
