I could use words such as 'profound' and 'insightful' when describing Inside Out, instead, I would like to share my experience of the movie..I took my 6 year old son, out of school to watch Inside Out as it was the last showing, in our local movie theatre, and it is not a decision I regret at all.After having watched this beautifully animated movie together, it has become so much easier to explain all the warring emotions in my little boy's mind. And, it has helped me rationalize my own actions and control my own emotions. Powerful? Definitely. And this message is so well wrapped in humour and fun.Can't wait for the DVD, it will be one that will be watched over and over again. Well done to the script writers, animators and the cast.

reviews.review_title: Probably Pixar's most emotional film ever!
reviews.content: Inside Out is a movie that's fun-filled with awesome characters, great setting, wonderful story and realistic situations. The story tells of Riley and the experiences she'll get when she moves to San Francisco. The story quickly transitions to the stage of puberty, wherein all the emotions try to take over and control the console. The real story begins when Joy and Sadness get separated from the group and try their best to return to Mind Headquarters to restore the damage they've done. With all the bumps and twists they'll come along, I assure you, its pure comedy, pure action, pure entertainment for the whole family. The characters have great personalities and are all suited for the story. Final verdict: This movie is sure to touch your heart,entertain the mind and make you cry (like 3 times).

reviews.review_title: Growing up can be a bumpy road
reviews.content: Growing up can be a bumpy road, and it's no exception for Riley, who is uprooted from her Midwest life when her father starts a new job in San Francisco. Like all of us, Riley is guided by her emotions: Joy (Amy Poehler), Fear (Bill Hader), Anger (Lewis Black), Disgust (Mindy Kaling) and Sadness (Phyllis Smith). The emotions live in Headquarters, the control center inside Riley's mind, where they help advise her through everyday life. As Riley and her emotions struggle to adjust to a new life in San Francisco, turmoil ensues in Headquarters. Although Joy, Riley's main and most important emotion, tries to keep things positive, the emotions conflict on how best to navigate a new city, house, and school.

reviews.review_title: From a twenty year old, this is an amazing film, an absolute must see!!
reviews.content: So the film is set in the extremely colorful and fantastical world of Riley's mind, where 5 emotions (Joe, Fear, Anger, Sadness and Disgust) control and guide Riley through her life. The premise is simple and has a clear set of rules which makes it perfect for children and adults. The film aims to explore the complex idea's of memory, personality (to name just a few)and the affect they have on Riley's life and wow they do this beautifully with vibrant and colourful characters that are extremely well developed while staying simple, playful and entertaining.Throughout the film we are treated to simple but enjoyable humor that had me in stitches.Writing this a a 20 year old man i should be the worst type of audience to connecting and enjoy this film (cough, frozen) as i should be too old to connect with Riley and too young to connect with the parents but thank everything i was wrong, it is fantastic a must see, and if anyone feels the need to compare it to frozen, they're doing this film an injustice.Beautifully written, fantastical world, and a story and meaning behind it that rivals the animated films of old. A 10/10 must see for anyone!!!

reviews.review_title: A great movie to get a better concept of how we work
reviews.content: As a psychology student I was very intrigued to watch this movie. I had heard a lot (positive) about it, so my expectations were high, and although it was different than expected, it was also fulfilling my expectations. Of course it is simplifying the way our brain works, but I think they still did a great job representing certain faculties of our brain.What I think was also great were the characters, they weren't flat, but you can definitely see how Joy and Sadness develop throughout the movie. I also love that in a way the movie contains two plots that are however intertwined in a very unusually close way. I also love that the movie shows how different feelings interact with each other and how sad moments can have something happy and valuable to them, while other happy moments might have a sad touch as well.Finally, I think that it is not inappropriate for children, as some people have stated here. I think people underestimate how capable children are of understanding these kind of things. Especially young children, they understand on a different level, but sometimes even better than some adults do. I love that this movie is not promoting any kind of consumer goods, like sugary food or certain role images (a girl that is into ice hockey, love it!) which is what other movies still need to learn!

reviews.review_title: You need to look deeper into this film y'all
reviews.content:
Many people keep calling out this film for being very depressing, poorly-developed, or whatever other reason that I don't think I can understand. But the problem is, you don't look deeper into it. Do you really expect your children to understand depression, or expect life to be all peachy and happy and beautiful and sunshiny?
Newsflash, you're ignorant. This is not reality.
As a person with depression, this film hit me hard. There's always a part of you that wants to deny the emotions that come with growing up, you want to remain happy, or neutral at the very least, for the people you love who are surrounded by stress. But in truth, when you try to avoid them, it only makes it worse. This film taught me to embrace my emotions, and be open with it to the people I trust. I was in tears as I watched this film, because while the situation was not the same as what I was going through, the emotions Riley felt and what I felt were very similar. It was what I needed to help me heal from the emotional pain that I was going through at the time. It isn't easy to teach your children that they cannot avoid pain or depression forever, so I say Inside Out is a good start to teaching them that. 
Inside Out, to me, is the best Disney movie. Emotions are a complicated topic reduced to a very simple concept in this movie. It's colorful, funny, and imaginative, all surrounding a complicated yet beautiful tale of how your feelings are normal and shouldn't be pushed away, but rather, you should be honest about them in order to heal. thank you, and goodnight. -drops mic-
Deep. I didn't really care until i saw that dude's sacrifice.
This movie manages to touch on so many levels. I laughed and even shed a few tears at some at some point. Highly recommended.

At first sight, I thought this movie was going to be another animation movie like thousands of them but I was completely wrong. What such a fantastic and original movie!I had to take a little time to get used to each character and their personality. At first, I didn't know what character was talking about, but after that brief moment you'll hooked on the movie.The plot is about the thoughts and feelings which are inside of the mind of a little 12 years old girl and how these feelings are represented by each one of the characters that appears in the story: anger, joy, sadness, disgust and fear. Each one of these characters has been pretty well represented and characterized being so easy to identify yourself with one of them. You will love it!The story will take you into different stages, involving each character mentioned above. The movie has everything and you will feel that anger, joy, fear, sadness and disgust of the little girl and her feelings. My recommendation is preparing some Kleenex for the final part of the movie. You will probably need it. It is difficult for me to express what this movie represents. It is completely different to other animation films. Just run to watch it. It deserves each minute. Looking forward to watching the second part of Inside Out! I really hope Walt Disney is working on it!

Inside Out is the latest Disney Pixar movie from Oscar winning director Pete Doctor, best known for his work with other classics like Up, Monsters Inc., and the Toy Story movies. The film centers on the emotions that help to guide the life of a 12 year old girl named Riley. Joy, voiced by Amy Poehler, is the predominant emotion and serves as the leader inside Riley's head. As a result, Riley is a very happy and relatively care-free girl who greatly enjoys her life in Minnesota. However, things take a turn when her family moves to San Francisco for her father's work.In Minnesota, Sadness, voiced by Phyllis Smith from The Office, was a relatively marginalized part of Riley's subconscious. However, as the family moves, Sadness begins to play a growing role without either her or any of the others really understanding why. Her actions lead Joy to try even harder to maintain control and keep Riley happy. However, those efforts result in calamity when she and Sadness are accidentally sent to another part of Riley's mind. As a result, Fear, Disgust, and, primarily, Anger are left to try and guide her through the tumultuous experience of adjusting to a new school and a new life while Joy and Sadness try to make the difficult trip back.Over the course of their journey, Joy gains a greater appreciation for Sadness and the role she needs to play in Riley's life. Joy learns that for Riley to function, she can't always be happy and that there will be times where the other emotions need to take on a greater role. Ultimately, it's only when she steps aside and allows Riley to actually express her sadness without bottling it up that the young girl is able to cope with the move and embrace her new life.Inside Out offers an entertaining yet powerful reminder of the need for emotional honesty. There may be times where it is necessary to set aside grief or anger in order to properly address the situation at hand, but when bottling up those emotions becomes a pattern it can only end in disaster. Jesus is perhaps our greatest example for understanding the benefits and the correctness of emotionally honest expression.Joy is manifested throughout his life and ministry but is perhaps best seen in the delight he takes when interacting with children and his disciples. However, we also see the other emotions displayed at various points in his life. He lived a sinless life but shows righteous anger and disgust when throwing the money changers out of the temple (Matthew 21:12-13). And he shows fear and sadness in the Garden of Gethsemane when he prays repeatedly for a way to avoid the cross if God's will could still be accomplished by doing so (Matthew 26:36-46).Ultimately, Jesus understood that while control was necessary, so was appropriate emotional expression. His life demonstrates a level of balance that can only be achieved when we realize that each of our emotions has its proper, God-given place in our lives. Acting otherwise by attempting to marginalize some aspect of our nature, whether it be sadness, anger, or any of the others, can prevent us from living the kind of life to which God has called us. In that way, it is quite similar to sin even if we may not often see it as such.So which emotions do you struggle to express? Why is that? Knowing the answers to those questions and acting on that knowledge are the first steps towards greater balance and the ability to live the kind of full life for which God has created you.So the next time you are tempted to set aside your first emotional impulse, stop and ask why that is. It may be that such action is necessary for the moment but never make it a pattern. Such repression is not healthy and, more importantly, it's not God's will for your life. He created you for more than that so live accordingly and you will know the kind of joy and peace that can only come from a well-balanced life.

I absolutely love this movie
I've seen it countless timesIt's well written with a great story all star cast and stunning visual effects
The analysis of each emotion is well represented and is very relatable to Riley's age.I'm not sure why this movie gets a lot of hate but it's a fantastic movie and I highly recommend it

Tears in my eyes of laughter and of being moved by Riley's emotional rollercoaster. What a superb coming of age, this story is brilliantly put together. Everything fits so,so good storywise and is displayed in such an imaginative manner that I bow my deepest bow for the artists responsible. In my opinion it should have won best film in 2016 Oscars, hands down. Mandatory watch for all movielovers.
Is a beatifull history. I love you. Is very interesting history.
Suspenseful, funny, sad and joyful at the same time, awesome. Purely amazing. Great as a family movie and not only.

reviews.review_title: Inside Out: A Metaphor about How to Interpret Emotions in our Lives
reviews.content: When a movie besides entertainment, is visually attractive and has a good script, it is definitely a success; when this film is also able to teach us a lesson of life and invites us to reflect, it is a wonder.THE MOVIE:Inside out, disguised as an animation film "apparently" for a child audience, tells the story of a girl and what happens with their emotions based on different events in her life. However, although suitable and enjoyable for any audience, in the face of a critical look we can find many metaphors about life itself and a deep insight into how the human emotional system works, and even we can find the influence of today's society, that often invites us to feel constantly happy.EMOTIONAL SYSTEM:It seems that humans and most animals come with a set of basic emotions. Some authors divide those in primary emotions (anger, joy, fear and sadness) and secondary (love, surprise, shame and disgust). These emotions are what help us in the task of understanding how we feel about the actions that happen or occur around us, and act accordingly to them. It is a reaction that thinking from an evolutionary point probably helped us (and help us still) to survive, in fact, the emergence of emotions is usually accompanied by somatic responses of the body as change of the blood pressure or release of various hormones by glands. However, presently, there are cases that may pose more of a handicap than a real advantage. One of the most common examples in today's society is "glossophobia" or fear of public speaking, apparently in today's society presents no evolutionary benefit, rather the opposite.From a physiological point of view, the generation of emotions has been linked to the model of "triune brain" proposed by Paul MacLean. The limbic system, known as the "old mammalian brain" is the origin of emotions and instincts, especially the amygdala, which is considered a primary structure facing the management of emotions as well as the hypothalamus, which is responsible for vegetative changes accompanying emotions, and to finally store the information obtained through emotions in the hippocampus. Moreover, the neocortex, which is part of the most developed mammals, is responsible for more complex actions such as reasoning or abstract thinking. Specifically the prefrontal and frontal lobes are responsible for managing and coordinating such emotional reactions trying to slow down the limbic system.EMOTIONAL ANALOGY IN THE MOVIE:In movie we can see some animated characters playing the role of basic emotions such as Happiness, Fear, Sadness, Anger and Disgust. Everything seems to be emotionally right on course for Riley, until her family suddenly decides to move and that emotionally destabilized her. In the following lines I make references to some ideas that are narrated in the movie (if you have not watched it yet, do not keep going!). These ideas have from my perspective a direct association with real life, the personality of the individual as well as their values and emotions."That is fear, he is good at making Riley be safe". This thought invites us to think what I said previously, fear kept us alive evolutionarily speaking - The main memories that are mentioned in the film can be viewed as a similarity of those events that have marked and have had a strong influence on our personality and future steps. - "Personality islands are what make Riley Riley" The islands are those values or activities that characterize a person and its personality, we see that as these islands are "disconnecting" in the film, Riley ceases to be herself, turning into a soulless child. - And once the night falls and we start sleeping, all our memories of the day pass to the area of long-term memories, that is, our daily events are becoming part of our experience. - Finally memories that have lost their importance, fade and can not be remembered Those things that once were important, slowly degrade and disappear. - The whole mess starts when Happiness tries to prevent a sad main memory from being introduced in the system of emotions of Riley (this can be associated with a situation where we try to remove feelings like sadness or anger, rather than understand them). - Finally, Happiness realizes that some happy memories had its beginning in a sad situation, what helps her to understand that sadness is as necessary as happiness. Finally and from my opinion, it is sadness from the idea of missing her family which leads her to decide not to run away.FINAL THOUGHTS:Following the reflections of the film and keeping the idea of ​​how our brain works and has worked from an evolutionary point of view, emotions help us understand how we feel towards both internal and external events that happen to us. Emotions can be mixed and one can lead to another, it is common to see how an event can trigger one initial emotion, which gradually evolves and turns into another. Society invites us to be single-emotionals and be always happy, but that is not the case and it is probably not even healthy and deprives us of the possibility of understanding how we feel. In fact, authors as Plutchik have begun to introduce these ideas in recent years. But it is also negative to hang on to emotions and do not let them pass. We all have met people who are wrapped with a hatress halo or have an aura of sadness (depressed); and they might even try to make you feel the same. Emotions play an important role in who we are, in our daily path and to be able tot ake us where we are heading. They are a powerful tool, but also extremely dangerous, you have to accept, understand and act according to what you have learned through them.

In my opinion, this movie is just a tad overrated. Here we'll start with what I deem the most important aspect to every movie's entertainment: characters. That's right, if I don't care about one or more of the movie's characters, it's hard for me to get into it. Now, I wouldn't say that Inside Out's characters were bad per se, however I would say they were pretty one-dimensional, particularly the 5 emotions. But how could they not be to some extent though? After all, they're all basically single emotions personalized into physical beings, rather than a whole human character. Therefore, I'll first state that I have no problems with how the scriptwriters have handled them, considering that there aren't really any other options in regards to how they could've written them. But that in itself is a problem I have with the entire concept of the movie. Now, as a whole, the concept is a very clever and innovative one; it explains how our minds work through creative metaphors and analogies that are easy for the audience to grasp. But for this concept to work, the characters of the personified emotions would have to only be limited to the traits of the emotion they are meant to represent respectively, otherwise they would miss the point of their respective character altogether. Thus, they'd have no choice but to be confined in stereotypical boxes, with not much space for their personalities to be expanded upon, thus they become predictable and repetitive after a while. This wouldn't be much of a problem for people who pay more attention to the general concept and storyline, as the character's interactions would be enough to keep them entertained during the filler parts, but as I said, I really want to focus on the characters when watching a movie, and relying on interactions(no matter how meaningful or entertaining) solely just isn't enough for me. So I guess this concept just isn't for me, though I do think of it as clever and charming.Now on to the main human character, Riley. I'll start by saying that I really like how they distanced her from stereotypes as much as possible. She has both a girly and a boyish side to her, for example. And there's also a bunch of random traits and preferences thrown into her character, like hating broccoli, goofball etc. To be honest, I liked this, as I do think that our personalities are comprised of many different traits and preferences which all stems from our reaction to past experiences. Some of these traits make us seem like a walking stereotype, while others make us seem like a walking contradiction. However, the problem I have with her character is exactly the opposite of the problem I had with the emotions'. When the emotions interacted together, you could see that they were all bursting with their own personalities which made them very distinguishable from each other. They were like a rainbow when joined together, however each one of them only represented their own respective color, and if you examined them on their own, they turn into a one-dimensional stereotype, like when you take one color out of the rainbow and focus on it, it will seem bland and flat to your eyes. But put them together, and you get a very colorful image. As for Riley, it's like taking a bunch of different colors and mixing them together, only to get a murky saturation. Sure she has a bunch of traits mixed into her character, but none of them are developed enough, and so they remain just general traits that just sort of mix together to make up a bland, uninteresting character that I feel indifferent about.Another(albeit minor) complaint I have is that the film seems to drag on half-way through, specifically when Joy and Sadness are trying to navigate their way back to headquarters. The whole journey just seemed to drag when I was watching the film, and my interest waned. That's not to say that there are no entertaining moments throughout the film, however, as there are certainly moments of charm and humor shared between the characters. Not to mention the little moment shared between Sadness and Bing Bong (definitely one of my favorite moments in the film, as it was inspiring, moving and powerful all at the same time, and it was an important scene of foreshadowing towards the end) and of course, when Joy and Bing Bong were trapped in the memory dump (though I wasn't quite as moved at the scene as most people were, because I found it predictable and wasn't too attached to Bing Bong's character in the first place). However, aside from those two important parts, the rest of the journey seemed mundane, and while there were the aforementioned charming moments littered here and there across it, they felt too short and fleeting to enliven the entire journey for me, so the sense of boredom still lingered throughout the course of the movie.So, those are my main issues with the film. Like most people here, I felt that the end scene was truly amazing, as it captured the feelings of longing and reminiscence perfectly, allowing for an empathetic bond to form between the audience and main character. It has moved me in more ways than one, it has deeply inspired me with it's message of emotional intelligence, and that is no easy feat. Yet, the movie manages to do just that with one scene alone; it was that powerful. Overall, I would say that the movie is successful in presenting the difference between the feeling of suppressing an emotion and the feeling of actually feeling that emotion. For that, I would say I liked it overall. But the issues I had with it (particularly in regards to the character department) definitely dampened my experience of viewing it. Thus, I'd say that I probably don't favor it quite as much as most people on here do.

reviews.review_title: Inside Out is about a little girl with some wild emotions.
reviews.content: Inside Out is a unique Disney movie that puts the princesses in the dust. If you are someone who doesn't mind a different style of a Disney movie, but with the same thought-felt emotions, this is the movie for you. Inside Out takes you on a crazy adventure of a 11 year old girl named Riley. Different from other movies, this movie you literally see the emotions of a human. We have joy, sadness, fear, anger, and disgust. With these polar opposite emotions, we see a new side of a person. What happens when someone "pushes your buttons?" In this movie, you see it all. I think it's a very thought out movie, with our brains becoming the headquarters for our thoughts and emotions. Watch this beautifully animated film and see how Riley's actions affect her emotions, and vice versa. It is a little technical with all the action going on at once, so I'd say teenagers and adults might enjoy this more than children. Whatever genre of film you prefer, this one will surely make you feel all the emotions. See what I did there?

reviews.review_title: I don't understand how people say that this film is bad for kids
reviews.content: For example, you have kids and you're busy with work like the father in the film, if your kids have watched this film, maybe they will understand that it's not you don't want to be with them and it's not you don't love them anymore. And when their feelings are messed up like Riley, they can understand that they're letting their emotions rule them. And they should tell you so everyone can sit down and find a solution for that problem. And I think it also reminds you of every treasure moments of your life by how it has affected your personality and your life. Maybe I'm a weirdo or something but to me, this film is good.

reviews.review_title: Amazing movie loved it a lot!
reviews.content: This is such a good movie because I have 2 kids and they wouldn't stop laughing during watching this. I can not believe where they get these ideas from but it was a really good idea and my kids loved it. A lot of people love this movie because it is kid friendly and a good movie to watch when you are bored it will make you cry laugh 😂😂

This is a pretty Good movie; One Of Pixars Best. First of all, i want to say its originality is what Drew me towards it. Although there might be something similar, I Don't Watch Anime and i'm not Chinese so there's not much i can say about that. Of Course, the animation is great, too.The Only Reasons i didn't rate it 10 is because a large majority of the time was with sadness; i also wanted more time with anger, disgust, And fear.My Grandam And me Agree that this movie was great; My Favorite part was when the Puppy dies ( Reference, and just kidding. ) 9/10, One of my favorites

reviews.review_title: Suddenly, in a new city, 11 years old Riley finds her emotions in a state of turmoil and struggles as she continues to lose all her personality traits one by one.
reviews.content: Inside Out is the 15th feature film released by Pixar Animation Studios and continues the tradition of creating animated features that cater to multiple age groups by combining a vibrant, colorful and entertaining narrative that captivates kids while having a complex central theme that engages the adults. The film features young Riley from Minnesota who has five manifestations of her emotions in her mind - Joy, Sadness, Fear, Disgust and Anger. The emotions influence her and control her day to day decisions and memories . When Riley turns 11, the family moves to San Francisco which puts her in emotional turmoil as she is a shy kid and finds it difficult to cope with a new environment. The resulting scenario leads her and her emotions to learn the importance of Sadness in life. The film received rave reviews on the back of stellar performances by the voice cast led by Amy Poehler as Joy and Phyllis Smith as Sadness. Phyllis shines with her convincing rendition of the meek Sadness. Lewis Black, Mindy Kaling and Bill Hader as the remaining emotions also give strong performances. Director Pete Docter excels at paying attention to detail. For example Riley's controlling emotion is shown to be Joy whereas her father is controlled by Anger and her mother by Sadness. Docter also succeeds in his attempt to create a model of the mind which is flexible enough to serve the purpose of the story yet is well thought out and consistent enough to stand on its own. This was achieved through consultation with Paul Ekman, a well-known psychologist who studies emotions, and Dacher Keltner, a professor of psychology at the University of California, Berkeley. While the basic concept is strong, the story suffers from periods of inactivity and monotony. The film seems stretched and could have done without a few of the scenes that were left in by the director. The movie also has a disconnect with the younger section of the audience because unlike other Pixar movies, the light-hearted and downright funny moments are few and far between. The core element of the story is complex for kids watching and hence might not enjoy the movie as much as the adults that accompanying them. The movie is a visual treat that leaves the audience with a smile on their face and a sense of fulfillment although with a little heavy handed editing the movie would have been even better.

reviews.review_title: A hilarious and thought provoking film for the whole family
reviews.content: You may have a slightly altered view of your own emotions or your family and friends after seeing 'Inside Out', Pixar's latest film. It's about a little girl, Riley, the only child of adoring parents. Her happy demeanour and idyllic life in rural America are threatened by a stressful move to San Francisco for her father's work. Most of the action takes place inside Riley's head where a Star Trek like bridge provides a command centre for Riley's emotions represented by 5 different cartoon characters: Joy, who is usually in charge; Fear; Sadness; Disgust and Anger. Other areas of the brain such as the subconscious and memory are also inventively represented. The film brilliantly and hilariously demonstrates how the conflict raging inside Riley's head between these emotions manifests itself on the outside. The 5 characters each take turns as the storyline progresses to steer Riley through the move, starting a new school and the other challenges she faces and we see how hard it is for them to avoid behaving true to type even though they all clearly want the best for her and things are reaching crisis point. The story will resonate with anyone who has ever relocated against their will but could leave anyone with thoughts and ideas that may help to make sense of everyday life. Next time I am feeling down I will recall what a genuine 'drag' Sadness was for Joy as the latter was forced to haul her through the labyrinth of Riley's long term memory corridors because she was 'too sad to move'. Fear is a neurotically thin figure whose attitude in the film will serve to remind what a waste of mental energy that emotion can be. We all know real life versions of these two and may try to limit our exposure to them but watch how the film deftly reminds you how useful sadness and fear can each be on occasion too – just like the drippy neighbour who is great at fixing things or the dowdy colleague who is a good listener. You will similarly see the usefulness in the right place of Anger and Disgust. I viewed this film with 3 generations of my family and we all enjoyed it enormously. Many PG and U certificate films can entertain for a couple of hours but it's a rare one that has the potential to inform and delight a happy family or re-unite a troubled one.

i can't believe the run of great films that pixar has to its credit. i can't think of a single misfire in the bunch and inside out is one of the very best. they took a seemingly silly concept -- our emotions personified -- and made it into a brilliant and emotionally resonant piece of art. i can't believe how good this film is.

As someone who has been manic-depressive my entire life, an inheritance from the Sherman side of the family, I was delighted to finally see a portrayal of it, particularly of the depressive side, as a condition, not a disease. The spoiler here is that it is depressive side (sadness) which helps Riley find herself. Our depressive side is the root of our greater compassion and sympathy; It is when we are sad that we best hear the sadness of others. Our manic side is the root of our greater energy to solve problems, heedless of the risk to ourselves; it is when we are ecstatic that we dare to end the cause of the sadness of others.The world needs manic-depressives and would be a far worse place without them. What manic-depressives need more than anything else is family and community to ease the high and lows, but to emphasize that would be to treat manic-depression, not as a disease seeking a cure, but as a condition needing the nurture of a home, as this movie does.

reviews.review_title: Likable, frustrating at times, Pixars finest....... Maybe not
reviews.content: We are a "Disney" family as my wife would say, my daughter is nearly 5 and we love most things Disney and Pixar. I had high hopes for this, perhaps too high and that is where my frustration lies. Where Wall-e succeeded in being a great film with little dialogue, this felt the polar opposite, with too much dialogue and repetition and way too little humour for a film of this genre. The trailers are I'm afraid the funniest parts of the film, but few other bites of humour emerge anywhere else in the film. Where this film succeeds, however, is in its ability to still captivate the imagination and draw you in! Despite having its flaws I still enjoyed this film and most importantly so did my little daughter. It is a little dark at times but hardly throughout and it's still suitable for young kids, just be aware that if you are expecting a multitude of slapstick humour and silly jokes aplenty then you will be disappointed. Go in open minded and having not watched the trailers and you may get more of a buzz from it!

I saw this movie today with my 4.5 y/o daughter and 3 y/o son. Daughter was very excited to see the movie and I thought it looked cute in the trailer. The movie started out hopeful but then it got really depressing and dark. I was actually upset watching this movie - that's not something that I can say has ever happened. It never really turned into the "happy ending" for me. It was depressing, then there was a sad moment (I shed some tears) then somewhat upbeat. My two really only understood the emotions when someone was crying so, to them, this movie was great. For me, it sucked!Also, the animated short that played before the movie "Lava" was also very depressing.

I went into Inside Out with pretty high hopes. I had heard from podcast people and critics that this movie was absolutely fantastic and I agree. I think it was a good movie, creative, great to look at, and had funny and sad moments. I just didn't connect with it as much as I wanted to. I think that could have something to do with that fact that I'm 19, so I don't really have that parental experience that I think grown ups connected with and I'm too old to relate to the emotions that I went though as a kid. I think one of the reasons why I felt a little disappointed is because I expect these epic or beautiful adventures from Pixar now. I don't really think this adventure was very epic. I never felt the sense that if they died or if they didn't succeed in their task, the world would end. Although I agree emotions are powerful, I didn't really think Riley's running away was drastic. It was also so predictable that I think that ruined any kind of suspense that the movie could have had. I also felt like the emotions besides Joy, Sadness, and the imaginary friend weren't fleshed out enough. They all seemed like comic reliefs and if they weren't in the story, it wouldn't have changed the plot. I know I sound like I'm attacking this movie but I did like it! I thought it was a beautiful movie and certainly had moving parts. I liked the characters and the message, but it just didn't personally stick with me compared to Wall-e, Up, or Toy Story which are the kinds of powerful movies I expect from Pixar now. I feel like this is a movie that could be particularly good for parents and kids because those are the two age groups that have a strong connection to the characters. Maybe in a few years I'll find this more moving, but at my stage in life I wasn't as satisfied with it as I wanted to be.

Back in 2015, when Inside Out first hit the theatre, I was forced to join my brother on the trip to go see it. And yet, even then, as a 12 year-old with a mere perception no better than a child, I was still entranced by the cutting-edge animations (I mean it's Pixar we're talking) and the rather pacing yet interesting plot-line. Those were, however, As much as an adolescent can get, the definite messages and meanings of menial scenes and details - which I think were profoundly and minutely appended for the sake of expanding the process of solely watching the movie to learning and attaining something from it - were obscure and obsolete to me at that point in time.The reason why this is necessary to be acknowledged is that, 6 years later, as a teenager who is on the brink of understanding who he is as a person and repositioning himself into the world of adulthood, I do think this is one movie that all children and adolescents should watch and understand, even if it is hard to, to grow, and to be mindful of the cruciality of nourishing and controlling the states of their own, to be uninfluenced by others, their lives, their emotions are their, and should be determined by themselves.Inside Out by Disney poses incredible lessons and meanings through phenomenal ability to push the audiences further and further in their own thoughts to explore and seek the ultimate message, that line that culminates the whole experience and, in the end, completes it. What did I found?Nothing, there was nothing there.Through my whole magnificent expedition in the land of emotions and memories, I was totally embarked completely in exhilarating moments after moments of overlapping excitement, as if there was nothing there, and until the very near-end, I was lost and left with nothing. The captivity and fascination took me all the way, I was constantly thinking, browsing through my thoughts and memories whilst trying to seize as much details from the scenes as possible, it was so interesting that I was lost completely in the movie, and until the very finish line, I looked back and was immediately packed with countless flows of perceptions and views that I had to write it down.Inside Out, in the utmost apparent manner, tells a story of emotions, in particular Joy, Sadness, Anger, Disgust and Fear. The Five collectively control the fundamental mental states of Riley, a young little girl whose life preceding was filled with happiness with mom and dad, friends, Hockey, and many more. But then because of certain issues, their family had to move away, that's where problems came in, big sudden changes never bring about good news. Small room, busy parents, new classes, new people, led to quarrels between the emotions, and then Joy and Sadness got lost, and while they were on their journey trying to get back, Riley had to live her life with only disgust, anger and fear, imagine how that would be, everything in her life fell apart. As for Joy and Sadness, through different twists and turns, coming against all sorts of unwanted dilemmas and plights, Joy started to understand the true purpose and importance of sadness. Upon going back, they developed their realization of the indispensability of one another and ended with a quintet working together creating balance and great symmetry within Riley's emotional states.I was lost in the story telling and filled with emotions in every bit of the way, and in that scene where Riley came back to her parents, and Sadness took control, I couldn't help but let the tears come out of my eyes. Such a heartfelt, strong, exciting, moving movie and I have to give props to the writers and the producers from Disney on Inside Out and many more of course.So, this is what I think:From far and wide, I do reckon the writers have captured the essence of communicating an effective plot that Inside Out can be seen and appreciated by almost every person from every year of age. By telling the story with characters that are so abstract, by bringing them to life and allow them to narrate, the writers force us to think outside of what's happening in the movie alone, because emotions are things all of us possess the courses of actions we are seeing can be the exact same of what happen inside our head as well. We as viewers are tempted to visualize and correspond using our own experience and awareness. And through that, we start to understand more about Riley, she was a happy girl, but one simply can't be happy ceaselessly, not because she can't; but sometimes, sadness brings people together, it helps people listen, it helps people sympathize and empathize, it helps people slow down, it helps people cry, be patted in the shoulders: "you've done well, next time will be great", and eventually come back up, better, learned, and loved, isn't that what does best in connecting humans? What I took away most from the movie is that: Emotions are there, they won't go anywhere, it is our job to keep it how we want it, uninfluenced by anything, strong, stable, and use them wisely to live how we want, because our emotions affect intensely our behaviors, and however we behave will decide our relationships, our careers, and ultimately, our lives.Ultimately, such movies like Inside Out are really important to be acknowledged and appreciated nowadays because they present lessons and messages that can help people realize numerous good things in their lives and live better, for themselves, and for everyone else around them.Recommended

The featured review on this page states that this movie requires a trigger warning. A Pixar movie is so emotionally impacting, that it is stirring up and genuinely pushing people over the edge with emotions. I don't think people realize and appreciate how hard this is to achieve through CGI, so kudos to Pixar for taking the torch into unexplored depths of the cinematic world.I went into the movie depressed, and came out more depressed. Digging deeper and deeper into the opening 30 minutes of the movie brought me to tears when I looked back at all my memories and how they've crumbled and been shut out over the years, just like what happens to our vulnerable Riley throughout the film. Does that automatically entail a bad review, having a movie stir me up emotionally and breaching facets deeper than I ever could've by myself? Not at all. To see such a low rating over something is essentially ignorance.What I saw from start to end was a classic Pixar movie unfold, with plenty of beautiful themes to latch onto and make you forget about the harsh ride up to the climax of the movie, and that's all it is, like everything else in life... a ride. Just be ready to feel the need to get off early if you're more sensitive to the content presented, because this is not something we've come to expect from Pixar, but at the same time, it's everything we've evolved and grown to encounter from them eventually.See it with someone you trust, in case you are overly sensitive. There is no reason to dismiss a beautifully executed film if you can't internally handle it... just know what you're getting into ahead of time, don't expect a happy-go-lucky experience unless you're seeing it drunk or with an ignorant state of mind. The previews were really clear with the direction the movie was taking.

This is Pixar's masterpiece. I took my boys (4 and 6) to see it and although they enjoyed it, they will need to see it again in about 30 years. I laughed and cried throughout this movie and I won't go into the details here. This movie was about the beauty and strength of the human mind and told through a vehicle of outstanding imagination and incredible animation. I will see this again in the theater and will buy it on Blue Ray when it's released. Just when you think movies are out of ideas, here arrives a winner..out of the park..grand slam. I loved it. Best I have seen in years and it reminded me what movies are supposed to bring to us.

When I first got word about Pixar making a movie about emotions, I was amazed. As a big fan of Pixar' s work, I knew good stuff was coming. I wasn't expecting something this bad. Although the characters are compelling, and I did understand the fact that Riley's father suffered rage attacks and her mother suffered depression. I did understand the struggle of Riley and her emotions. But the script! Awful, every scene was the same as the one before and after. The personality islands shut down, they fall, and joy and sadness try to go back to the tower to save the day. Is there any fun in that? Because being honest here, kids movies are made to have fun. So yeah, those are my thoughts on Inside Out. Hope Pixar shoots higher and unlocks their true potential on "A Good Dinosaur".

reviews.review_title: BS-100 IJ17D021 KH.KHulan Inside Out review
reviews.content: I enjoyed the movie. I couldn't imagine how they would make a whole movie from the point of view of the human emotions, but it came out well. Father and mother both kind and loving to each other and the daughter. Suddenly, mind of daughter changes. Because her mind makes a trouble from inside out. Finally, Her mind understood most important thing of human life rules. The role of sadness as a vital emotion was really interesting. I liked that. I recommend it. reviews.review_title: Caught it with my 8 year old. Amazing movie. True to Pixar.
reviews.content: Great story which nicely bridges both a young and not so young audience. Great casting and tight story. Not too much meandering around in the long term storage scenes. Love the way it all ties together towards the end. The "human" characters are finally getting the right animation treatment so they don't look creepy. Make sure to stay for the outtakes at the end...quite funny.I'll definitely see it again to catch all the subtle backstory stuff. For parents, my youngest was thoroughly entertained and didn't get caught up in those segments where they try to describe what's going on in the brain. My daughter now firmly believes that there are these little guys in your head.

Inside out is an excellent movie, which isn't like many others. The movie features great examples of the impact emotions have on the youth. Certain scenes seemed so simple yet it had a deep meaning. The moment with Riley on the bus, where she realizes she's making a mistake, gives a deep feeling of acting in moments of anger and doing things without thinking and later regretting it, which goes along with fear. Also, the colors correlate with how the movie makes you feel. When sadness touched the memories and things went wrong, the colors changed from light and bright, to icy, blue, dark. Furthermore,Riley was pretty relatable. there were things that remind people of what their childhood was like. The scene with Riley being sad over happy memories, wanting to go back to the happy place, feeling sad when you miss things, those feelings hit really close to home.When you observe the emotions, you seem to realize sadness connects to some aspects of depression and fear connects to anxiety. People who grew up with negative mental development can see that Riley might have those two things. The way anger reacts without thinking shows how Riley can have an issue with impulse control. Joy having her hopes up and being let down shows how Riley begins to have lower expectations later on. I recommend this movie to people who understand these problems and have dealt with them. The point of the movie seems to be presenting feelings and dealing with growing up. The character development shows that Riley understands her feelings later on and works on controlling them. The parents' short seconds of inside of their heads shows that they knew how to control their emotions, they didn't seem to have the same issues as Riley considering they are adults. It seems that Riley is experiencing maturity and learning to be controlling of herself, which is part of growing up and learning to make the right choices. She hasn't made perfect decisions but she later learned from her mistakes. Other than the subject of maturity and learning, Riley also seems to see what it's like to be in a new place you don't want to be. She moved to a new city with a new house and she had a hard time adjusting. Adjustment problems seem to run with not trying to adjust, but only thinking about what you want and what you had. Seeing this, its telling you to learn to adjust to new things, the past is in the past.My favorite part was the childhood scenes. She still has some things from when she was younger in her head, like the imaginary friend. It shows that when you get older, some things can go further away in your mind, but they will always be a part of you. Aside from what is negative and positive, the end of the movie shows Riley coming across a boy who seems to like her, which was some comic relief after all the dramatic events occurred.This movie is a great example of showing mind development, control, and depth. You see Riley change for the better over time, you see Riley learning to control her feelings, and you see Riley learning to understand instead of just reacting. 10/10.

After the two underwhelming sequels(cars 2 and monsters university) pete doctor had a very unique idea for a pixar film and the movie turned out to be called Inside out. One side of the movie is about riley moving to san Francisco and how she has to face her new life. While the other side of the story is about how her five main emotions take care of her; Joy, Sadness, Anger, Disgust, and Fear. The main lesson of Inside out is that being sad is ok its part of life and being sad can show how you feel to other people but joy the protagonist really doesn't get what sadness really does. When joy and sadness get transported to long term memory by accident they gotta go threw many obstacles that are in the way like the area longterm memory or the subconscious. Bing bong is the one that lead joy and sadness to all those areas so they can find a way back but every time they try they fail because of what the other emotions are doing in headquarters. Theres one stand alone scene and that is the scene where joy and bing bong fall in to the memory dump. In this scene joy saw the importance of sadness and she learned the lesson that being sad is ok. Joy eventually escape but Bing bong doesn't make it out since he sacrificed himself to help riley, and joy is find anyway to make it back with sadness they eventually do and joy depended on sadness to help riley which she succeeds. Inside out is a very special movie that can really help people especially people with depression. Overall its one of the gems of pixar

reviews.review_title: Inside Out Gets It Right Side Up (Mostly)
reviews.content: From the studio that brought you movies like Toy Story, Monsters, Inc., and The Incredibles comes another great film, and one that I might add is not only enjoyable, but informative both for kids and adults. Inside Out is the story about the little "voices" in your head. Our characters in this movie are the emotions we feel. We have Joy, Sadness, Fear, Disgust, and Anger. Together they all navigate life in the head of 11-year-old Riley and learn important life lessons when Riley's life is shaken up due to a relocation of her family from Minnesota to San Francisco. Starring in this movie are Amy Poehler (Parks and Recreation), Phyllis Smith (The Office), Bill Hader (Saturday Night Live), Mindy Kaling (The Office, The Mindy Project), and Lewis Black (American comedian, Accepted).Inside Out is a movie more enjoyable than I thought it would be. It excels as a kids film in that it not only is designed with the intention of being a family friendly movie, but also being one that helps kids to understand something important about themselves through an understandable and concise plot. This movie centers around the emotional turmoil that takes place inside Riley's head when she relocates to a new town. Moving is stressful for anyone no matter what age you're at. For an 11-year-old, however, moving translates to getting used to a new school, having to make new friends, and finding new ways to keep up with your hobbies and interests. Dealing with all of that is a very large amount of change for someone young to experience. Through the emotions in Riley's head we see her slowly trying to acclimate to the new environment she's in, but as the movie goes on it's more than apparent that it's very difficult for Riley to see where she is as her new home. From here we are taken on a journey that tells us, the audience, that the feelings and emotions we have are important and definitely teaches kids that it's okay to not always experience joy or happiness in times of hardship.Read The Rest At http://www.dimthelightsfilmblog.com

Bleary-Eyed in the morning, putting on a jumper inside out, you might remark it as feeling different and a little uncomfortable. Flash forward to your exit out of the local cinema, and you would most likely think, "hmm...Inside Out", different certainly , yet wonderful in every sense of the word.After a 2014 hiatus, Pixar have returned to the Shark-Tank of Animated Cinema with the beautifully poised "Inside Out". Directed by Pete Docter, the film chronicles the cerebral happenings within an eleven year old sweetheart, Riley, but not as you would have anticipated. As the film tape rolls, we are introduced to Joy, Sadness, Fear, Anger and Disgust, whom all are minion-like personified emotions.Subtleties from past Pixar films are pulled out of the hat, although each one feels fresh and authentic for the viewer. Abstract ideas are explored vividly, akin to "Up" (Floating House/Personified emotions). Paradoxically, they seem to have expanded starting points for rather normal, to be expected scenarios, i.e An old man wanting to retire in Paradise and a child feeling uncomfortable in new surroundings. Also interesting is the dual narrative scampering along, first incorporated in "Finding Nemo". Funnily enough, the interacting emotions of "Inside Out" reminded me of the frenetic, yet somewhat Paranoid Fish Tank Residents, at 42 Wallaby Way Sydney!One has to remember too that Riley is cast as a protagonist. She's not an old man trying to ease into retirement, a shy robot abandoning Earth, or a hotshot race-car trying to win the Piston Cup. Instead, similar to Brave, Pixar have clearly pitched a protagonist as the archetype of whom they'd like to see enjoy the film; an eleven year old. From here, we are really treated to beautiful iconography including the Core-Island like relics of Riley's, surrounded by a metaphorical ocean of thought. I admire how the creators gently nudged us in this direction with the slapstick short "Lava" to get us thinking about islands, relationships, perspectives etc, which was a nice touch(Although now I can't forget the song about Volcanoes in love, but that's beside the point!). IA heart-warming message of compromise and perseverance pervades what is an entertaining, inspiring story. Laugh-Out-Loud hilarity ensues, most prominently thanks to Joy(Amy Poehler) and Sadness(Phyllis Smith). For Children, the characters are cutesy, funny and lovable and for a more mature audience(I'm looking at you, Parents!)the emotion caricatures typify a thread of relatability, a crack of vulnerability that brought a tear to the eyes of some at the screening I attended.If at all there were to be a caveat, I would say that perhaps there's too many clever ideas fighting for our attention. Bludgeoning us with abstract idea after abstract idea is like listening to a compilation of Power Ballads. Yes, there's potent stuff coming through the earplugs, but ultimately it all becomes a bit overpowering and eventually tiresome. In short, this is something the editing team back in California should have looked into more. This is where "Inside Out" has just missed the Boat. Where Classics such as "Up" and "toy Story" develop a couple of brilliant concepts(Floating House/Lost Expedition/Unlikely Friendship/Escapism etc)"Inside Out" reminds me of the Student at the Top of the Class that is just too perfect, too clever for their own good.All that said, "Inside Out" has to be up there as one of Pixar's most mature, palpable and adventurous films to date. It echoes a slightly experimental charm about it too. It feels like the product of a crazy brainstorming session in a Pixar Boardroom, deliberated over by a bunch of sleep-deprived, self-confessed geniuses living off Caffeine and Sheer will-power alone; you've got to hand it to them, haven't you?.Refined around the edges, "Inside Out" is essentially Pixar's Miss Congenial. It's a bit of everything that'll please and be adored by almost everyone, if a little too perfect at times.

Inside out will always be a treasure in my heart. The characters trick you to believe that you have them in your head. We all wish we could have a Joy in our heads just like Riley does. Everybody wants to be happy all the time but we all a Sadness, Anger, Fear, and Discussed, along with Joy. Even though Riley isn't happy all the time it shows the audience that its normal not to be happy all the time. As Rliey progresses in the movie, the emotions that she has get more and more controlled. Just like the audience . Inside Out was also created by Disney's Pixar productions. Some other movies also created by Pixar include Cars, Up, and Toy Story. So, if you love those you will certainly love Inside Out. Riley's "core memories" surrounds the entire movie that you will be at the edge of your seat. Without her core memories she isnt Riley. The emotions in her head do anything and everything to make Riley, Riley again! This outstanding movie could never get old.
Amazing movie from start to finish. Fun for all ages and inspirational.

Enjoyed it a lot.Great animation and creativity.When things go badly awry, Joy and Sadness are pitched out of the control room and dumped into the depths of Riley's long term memory an area bearing a shockingly multi-coloured resemblance to the Hall of PropheciesIn Riley's head brought vividly to life by Joy, Sadness, Anger, Disgust and Fear. Sitting - Star Trek Enterprise style - at a console somewhere behind Riley's forehead, they watch what's going on and control her emotions to suit.With no joy or sadness in her life, how can Riley cope? There follows a desperate mission to return Joy and Sadness to the HQ, aided and abetted by Riley's long-lost imaginary friend Bing Bong, before her life is permanently wrecked by bad decisions.Let's start with the positives on this film. Inside Out is enormously inventive. If the Indiana Jones series drove an interest in kids doing degrees in Archaeology, then the same could happen for Psychology as a result of this movie. At the very least, you can see how kids with issues of anger management or depression could really get genuine value out of this simple movie by visualising and therefore understanding their problems better.The sociological impacts of the movie might actually be quite profound.

An extremely entertaining guide for beginner "psychotherapists"! Inventive, multi-layered, with a wonderful invention in visualization, a lot of good jokes. More or less all American social clichés have been collected and played up, including the notorious scary clown (who even has two scenes, the second, though sarcastic, about six years of drama school). A very funny episode at the table when, caught off guard by Mom's silent hint, Dad's emotions (beautifully voiced by Kyle MacLachlan) are in dismayed horror, which makes his face look extremely stupid. And the emotions of a cat walking by themselves! :))
If anyone watched the American "The Office" - plump Phyllis (both in role and in life) perfectly voiced Sadness). Yes, and everyone did a good job, the result was very interesting.

The Pixar team takes us to unexpected places again in this exuberantly enjoyable adventure romp that has some serious, dark sides for adult viewers. The film sends us into the mind of an 11-year-old girl who is going through an alarming life change, causing a lot of laughter and tears. The script has remarkable psychological undercurrents as it explores dreams, abstract thinking and imagination, as well as a creepy visit to the subconscious. It is also notable for its clever message about the balance between emotions, how Joy and Sadness learn to accept each other and even work together. In other words, Riley is growing up, becoming more complex in how she thinks about what's going on around her. When she stops being a giggling little girl, dark emotions may play a more important role. Obviously, this depth will be lost on young children, but they have their own colorful film in which Joy and Sadness go through an inventive, exciting adventure. Joy anchors the film with its hilarious lines, most of which are clearly improvised, and other emotions are just as vivid, with a scene-stealing turn from Anger and a strikingly resonant performance of Sadness. Visually, the film is a great combination of colors and textures, balancing the dramatic weight with visual gags. This is one of Pixar's most exciting films, a film that engages children and adults in a vivid scenario and never lets go. Whether we're laughing at another witty joke or wiping away tears, we're completely caught up in how what's going on in Riley's head affects her mood and actions. It's just impossible to look at it without feeling every surge of emotion.

Five Emotions are practically described in this movie tremendously. Joy, Sadness, Fear, Anger and Disgust are the important part of our emotion. If anyone watch this movie, he/she can understand the logical change of our mind through these emotions.The movie is cortical to understand for the child.One of the best movie I ever seen.

reviews.review_title: Pixar's Proves They Still Got it and Then Some!
reviews.content: Hello fellow movie goers, critics, and all those in between, in this weeks edition we feature a very special critique coving Pixar's new film Inside Out. With out giving any spoilers this film takes you on a magical emotional adventure that you would be foolish to even consider missing. It's a brilliant film that finds an incredible way to bring to light the trials and tribulations that are growing up. Amy Poehler does an amazing job portraying the character Joy and is accompanied by an outstanding cast that bring this story that much more to life. It's a story like no other! A movie so heartwarming it will make you forget that your husband forgot to take out the trash yet again this week..As if it couldn't get any better to top it all of the movie opens with one of the most incredible Pixar shorts (the short alone is enough reason to get out and go see this film). This movie is a must see for people of all ages. So people get off those bums and treat yourself to the wonder that is viewing Inside Out.

A movie that shows the genius of Pixar's storytelling in a way that few of their other movies do. I love all of their movies, but the message and themes in Inside Out are on another level, making it incredibly relatable for parents, and enjoyable for kids. Our 3 year old daughter really enjoys it, and she obviously doesn't grasp all of the metaphors and relationships it so amazingly depicts. The voice acting is spot on, the way they've created the world within someone's mind is absolutely incredible, and the emotions this movie will cause you to feel run the gamut. My wife and I cried and felt incredibly happy at the same time. See this movie.

This review will be split into two parts. Part 1 is what I thought about it when I was a little kid, and Part 2 is what I think about it now.Part 1. When I was 7, this was a good 8/10; there was nothing better at the time. Seeing colors and different emotions walk around being funny and crazy was a really cool thing for me at the time. I took a liking to the Fear character to the point of begging my mom for a plushie of him like any 7-year-old would do.Part 2. Now, this movie is a solid 2/10. If I could rewatch it on Disney+, I would ask why we are on Disney+ in the first place. Stuff from Disney and Pixar has slowly faded out for me (with a few exceptions). When I watch an animated movie, I really only look at how smooth the animation is and if anything clips or bugs out and the animators didn't see it. Pixar did a great job, animation-wise. That is the only good thing I'll say about this movie.

This movie by the one and only Pixar films and the director that brought you many blockbuster films such as Up, Toy Story, Nemo and Monsters Inc. So you already knowhow good this animated film is going to be and it was! This movie was unique, creative and exciting. Without a doubt my favorite movie ever and I can watch over, and over, and over again! I give it a 10/10. I hope you agree with my opinion! Thank you Basic summary: Growing up can be a bumpy road, and it's no exception for Riley, who is uprooted from her Midwest life when her father starts a new job in San Francisco. Like all of us, Riley is guided by her emotions - Joy, Fear, Anger, Disgust and Sadness. The emotions live in Headquarters, the control center inside Riley's mind, where they help advise her through everyday life. As Riley and her emotions struggle to adjust to a new life in San Francisco, turmoil ensues in Headquarters. Although Joy, Riley's main and most important emotion, tries to keep things positive, the emotions conflict on how best to navigate a new city, house and school.

Or may be in the case this movie would participate in both categories.Thanks

reviews.review_title: Likes and dislikes of Inside Out
reviews.content: Riley is an eleven year old girl that is learning how to deal with her emotions. In inside out these emotions are actually characters that live inside Riley. They work every day at headquarters. Joy, Anger, Sadness, disgust, and fear. In the beginning of the movie the emotions seem to have very good control and work seems easy. When Riley has to move however, these emotions take on a big challenge. Many other emotions besides joy get a bigger workload. This is Riley trying to deal with her new environment. Joy is our protagonist in the movie. The conflict she reaches is getting lost in different departments of Riley. She views sadness as bad memories and therefore does not want sadness to influence Riley's memories. By the time Joy and Sadness make it back to headquarters Riley has figured something out. She had realized that sadness is a necessity in Riley's life. She also realized that joy is usually short to follow right after. This movie was a great depiction of what goes on in an eleven year old girl's brain. Riley can relate too many of the children that watched the movie. It really showed Riley's stage of depression quite well. I think the directors did a great job over all with this movie. This is the first Disney movie that focuses closely on our cognitive behavior. The directors did a good job personifying emotions everyone can relate too. Like most Disney movies they made you feel emotions. I think they purposefully made you feel the emotions that you were watching. This movie was suitable for children or adults to watch. It was intelligent enough to keep adults entertained. As for the kids it was just as cute, funny, and imaginative as all the other Pixar movies. The picture and scenes were absolutely beautiful as well. Colors definitely popped and seemed to change with Riley's mood. The thing that I did not like about this movie is how the emotions were thought to have control over Riley. When Riley went into depression it was because of accidents that happened in headquarters. Depression is natural and happens to many people. Emotions do not have control over that. I think it is more Riley's environment that has an effect on her emotions and it did not seem to show that. I think the movie would be much better if her environment had affected her emotions more and the emotions understood what was happening. Overall I would give this movie a four out of five stars. Inside out was able to keep me entertained throughout the whole movie. It had an ingenious plot and creative characters. If you have not seen this movie yet I definitely recommend watching it. Inside out is the perfect movie for family and friends and it is a movie any person on Earth can relate to. Seems to be that the Disney Pixar combination is working out quite well. If they keep producing movies of this caliber they will continue to be prosperous.

I'm not suprised this has been recieved poorly by many. This movie pushes back on how Americans view emotions culturally. However, we see the impact of our stifled view on emotions by the level of depression and anxiety in our society.Emotions need to be felt. They are an indication that something is happening. Not that they are the end all be all, but if we can tolerate distress we can navigate them effectively. Riley spends much of the movie not being able to name what is happening. Trying to just push through and be positive while ignoring what your body is telling you is damaging.We see her work through this and be able to share her sadness with her parents who love her where shes at. And it helps deal with the distress. This is called secure attachment. Kids and adults need it. Having someone you know cares doesnt make the crappy situation go away, but it makes it tolerable.The fact people cant tolerate the discomfort into this movie is telling. There is so much to be learned here.Want to learn more about these things? Check out the work of Dr. Dan Siegal and Dr. Sue Johnson.

If you love animation and Pixar, then you should watch this film. This was one of the most creative pieces of work Pixar has ever done! The characters are lovable and memorable, the story is very well-thought, and the lesson is touching. I'm going to say it again but if you love creativity and animation you should definitely check out this film.

reviews.review_title: Watched it as an adult and loved it
reviews.content:
I thought the complexity of the emotions were spot on and I really enjoyed it. I wanted to punch sadness in the beginning but all was forgiven by the end.
I laughed, I cried and I am a fan.

reviews.review_title: An Incredibly Touching and Enjoyable Watch
reviews.content: Pixar has done it again. The created a family friendly story that takes us on an emotional roller costar ride. Even though it is missing out on a lot of the other emotions but a feel like the primary generic ones are there. Maybe if the make an Inside Out 2: Puberty Edition they will included more, it probably has something to do with Riley's awareness of those emotions. Being able to look inside the minds of everyone and know what their thinking process is like is amazing. The scene at the kitchen table is one of my favourite scenes in the movie. Everyone who has gone through puberty would understand what Riley was going through. Inside Out is a movie that is relate able for viewers of all ages. All in all, I really enjoyed watching Inside Out tremendously.

Immediately after watching I was so disappointed and a little depressed. I thought how is this a Disney/Pixar movie? And it is definitely not for little ones! It should have a 10 and up rating. The next day I was still thinking about this film, it is very thought provoking and it deals with depression in kids today. So on the one hand I didn't like it because it was not a feel good Disney movie we are used to. But on the other hand if it can let preteens know they are not alone with depression then the movie is a success. Thankfully I don't battle depression but I know many that do. Trying to look at it from that point of view the movie make sense and if it can help kids learn to talk about their feelings then it was a success! I applaud them for trying to help kids with a very real problem in today's world.

Let me start by saying that this movie is not for kids. The movie is definitely geared more towards adults and has more of a message than many of the movies that are currently out. This is a definite must watch an incredibly underrated brilliant movie

After a second viewing I have settled on the problem I originally had and can now honestly say this film really just has nitpick issues, it's truly a great one and definitely the best we've been given in 2015 so far. After my first viewing I was all enthusiastic about everything above, but I also was left a little confused by the mythology the film uses and wasn't quite sure it always fit. Upon a second viewing I guarantee that there is no such problem. The mythology is perfect and works with a solid and thought out logic that takes into account the chaos of life. What doesn't quite work is the fact that the film does have a few really minor shortcuts or conveniences that may stick out and I honestly wanted a little bit more of the control center room scenes and see some more of how it worked there, but then again I am really nitpicking.Incredible for me to say it, but I really want a sequel to this film, it's incredible. I want to see another two hours of the five emotions battling in out in the life of Riley and her further struggles, especially want to see the teenage years. This idea is truly amazing and special and it is so inspiring to me, I just really want a sequel to this film and that's the first time I've ever said that in my life.
