reviews.review_title: Interesting Concept for a Kids Film
reviews.content: Watched Inside Out on the plane after everyone told me I was going to cry. Didn't cry, but I did take something away from it. Had a few chuckles as well. "Sadness" gave me a bit on anxiety. Talk about a depressing character, but I guess that was her role!

When i first saw the trailer, I was really excited to see it. I liked the concept of the movie, it was something that hasn't been done before. But it wasn't what I excepted*Warning:Careful for spoilers* The whole film they focused on the emotions, instead of Riley, the actual interesting character. The 'lead' emotions ,Joy and Sadness,were pretty annoying. But i liked the other 3 and wanted to see more of them but instead i got a very boring and slow adventure with Joy and Sadness. It was the worst part of the movie and it left like filler. The whole time when they were about to go back something occurred and were stuck there, again and again. It's predictable and annoying. But I liked the sacrifice of Bing Bong, that was an unexpected and emotional scene and it kinda waked me up after the boring scenesThe other parts of the film, were actually pretty good. The beginning with the whole explanation was nice and interesting and everything made sense. The ending were Rikey decides to walk away was also exciting, but for me it didn't make any sense because, where did she wanted to go? The scene were she starts to cry did nothing for me but the ending was nice, the funniest part was with the boy who had the 'girl alarm'.I give it a 7 for the great animation and the begin and end, but for the rest, it felt like a real bore. Sad, because it had great potential.
This movie shows what goes on inside your head with your emotions in cartoon form. i think it is a great movie. i also watched this in a support group at school

This movie is a very creative and extraordinary animation about Reley's life, she is eleven years old, she lives with her parents and she is very happy, but her life changes completely when something happens. Her mind is controlled by five emotions, happiness, fear, disgust, sadness and fury. They guide Reley in her new life, this emotions stay in a control room where they can see what happens in her day and create a emotional answer. Our opinion is that everybody should watch this movie because it makes we think about our childhood and value it, so if you want to remember your childhood, watch this movie. This animation is not only for kids because it brings a beautiful message for us.

"Inside Out", after my opinion, is a very strange Pixar story. While some people thinks this is a boring story, and some others thinks it's a very emotional and beautiful story. I like this movie because it's so original. If you're understanding the true meaning of how Riley is acting, because she has troubles in school and depressed by the new home, if you're understanding that part, you'll probably see the movie as a much darker story, with realities you can relate to in real life, rather than just a stupid silly adventure of 2 animated characters, who are lost in a fantasy world.What amazed me most about "Inside Out" then, is how the story managed to contextualize so much of this messiness, defining Riley in her final hours by the internal conflict between her stubborn and selfless sides, and demonstrating how this constant inner strife made her so many different things – needy, brave, impulsive, brilliant, isolated. It's not the very best Pixar movie I've seen, but it really delivers some originality that I haven't seen before. - Sorry for the bad English, I'm not very in to write reviews in English :)

The movie was and should be meant for children. It was commendable in screenplay and animation but in a scientific standpoint, the movie disappoints. In other words, it struggles to find any biological accuracy. It's no excuse for a Disney movie but overall it captures you for the whole length of the tittle.The movie starts with appointing a basic entity of every primal emotion of a little girl as she's born and grows up to be a teenager. The concepts or sadness, anger, long term memory and depiction of a savior in the name or happiness. Basically, the point it to keep the Joy doing it's work and not letting Sadness with the right mix of every emotion to keep the her ethically sound the help her adapt to the new situations and leaving hardships of moving on from her childhood home to focus on the life per se.

Inside Out is a lovely animation movie, fitting for all families. The title suits the movie very well. Indeed, the story is about a little girl called Riley and the emotions that make her personality. These emotions face challenges throughout the story line as Riley grows up and reaches her teenage years, especially when she has to move to San Francisco because of her dad's work. As Riley battles with real life, her emotions go through a journey of adventure inside her subconscious mind after a disagreement between Joy and Sadness.I enjoyed this movie very much. It gives us an insight on how we are all driven by our emotions and that having mixed emotions on any matter is completely fine. I guess you could say that's what makes us human! I had my doubts about it being a tad childish, but it appeals to viewers of all ages.The voice actors were particularly well chosen, as each one fits his or her character very well. The technicians in charge of the animated aspect of the movie have done a great job of making the emotions come to life and make the viewers personally relate to them. It doesn't come as a shock that Disney-Pixar has once again pulled off a great plot and an overall successful movie suited for every family night for everyone from child to adult.I would recommend you to go and see it with your loved ones

reviews.review_title: Movie is not for Kids, but one of the best movies.

Sometimes we are happy, sad, angry, anxious, and so much more. Our mood changes a lot. If we are sad that does not mean we should not try to be happy, but sometimes sadness is needed in our life too. This movie tells us how to live our life as a happy person. It is actually trying to show what is going inside our mind, and how all these moods affect our lives. Over all the movie was great, and I enjoyed a lot, but I felt bad for that five years old kid.

The movie gets into deepest emotions and personalities in humans in a funny way instead of being too serious all the time, as humans tend to be.Everything is not controlled about our emotions. This cartoon film I consider to be the best in all cartoon production. When I started to look at it, it was not at all clear to me how with the help of just five emotions it is possible to describe a human feeling. But the creators of this masterpiece it turned out incomparably. Of course, a person has more emotions, but if you show each one, then you need to shoot the series for a huge number of episodes. Although, this is not a bad idea. Each of the presented emotions is perfectly and very accurately shown. I am more than anyone, I liked Sadness. Strange, but true. When her joy dragged her leg, and she lamented, I laughed without stopping. I was also struck by a very precise moment with the erasure of telephone numbers in my memory. From animals having feelings, to technology having feelings, to even toys having feelings, Inside Out continues the trend with feelings having feelings. Its release in 2015 was more than anticipating with its general audience being young children.
 The movie started off with the birth of the main character, Riley. With that, it included how when each person is born, so are their emotions. Fear, Disgust, Anger, Sadness, and Joy, who was the first to appear. As Riley grew up, each of her emotions appeared as well of the making of each of her core memories. Everything begins to switch up and get off track when Riley and her parents move from Minnesota to San Francisco. From there Riley begins to experience different feelings such as low self esteem and low confidence.
 The story was setting off to the viewers what goes on in young children's minds. A move for example, as used in the movie, can effect a child greatly, mentally.

reviews.review_title: One of the best animated movies from Pixar
reviews.content: When I first clicked play I expected a whole lot of things from Inside Out. I expected at a point for the movie to be childish, I expected it at a point for the movie to not tell an emotional story like many of the Pixar past movies, and I expected the movie to be mediocre like the movies Pixar was recently putting out. Inside Out changed that all for me.Growing up with Pixar movies from, Toy Story, Monsters Inc, and The Incredibles I would never think in a million years Inside Out would somehow land on the top of my favorite Pixar movies. Pete Docter nailed this one and Inside Out just did that. Inside Out not only tells the story of an eleven year old girl growing up, but the brief sadness that comes with growing up. Even from the beginning, it had me thinking of me when I was young and how happy I was growing up in Pixar's golden age; through the beautifully composed score from Michael Giacchino.The movie originally makes you believe that the things you love will always and only contain happy moments, when really its the exact opposite. Everything you love, family, friends, and sports all have moments you are feeling not only happy with, but also sad and angry. Pete Docter nailed this. He also proved that sometimes some sadness will lead to some of your best happiest moments in your life.Inside Out was a pleasure to watch and brought Pixar back to making the most inspiring, creative movies that anyone has ever made.

reviews.review_title: Great movie, very thoughtful and emotional reasonable to watch, everyone should totally watch it
reviews.content: I mean...how do i start, I am not a good fan of animations and stuff like that but this movie was over the bad it was great and i think everyone should go see it, the voice-overs were great, the character were detailed and well portrayed in the film, exceptional and incredible. At first i thought that this movie was the worst like "what a hell" but even the tittle was great, and the cover, you know they say you can't judge a book(or movie) by it's cover because most films look "judgeable" but this movie is outstanding so it's a news to view the awards it got, and while some few might be like "blah, blah, blah...he's probably getting paid to say that", no am just a regular child who finds to label things in the most honest way i can think of..long story short, this movie is amazing, go see it! :)

Inside Out has a great animation, it is a beautiful movie. And while I dislike the fact that the human is limited to 5 emotions, I understand that it is a kids movie and would make no sense to complicate it with several kinds of emotions.My main complain is that it seemed by the trailers, that it would show us how the teenagers brain "works", what cause all of us to have that hard time in our lives. With that said, I thought everything would go wrong after some natural cause that happens with every teen by Riley's age. But I was really disappointed when all that mess happened because Sadness is a stupid pain in the ass, making the same mistakes over and over, and Joy is terrible and irritating manager.Well, then the movie is telling what happened with Riley's brain only, not what happens to all kids'. That clearly shows that her emotions are not normal, in this case even psychological help wouldn't help, she needs some medication to regulate those emotions. I didn't finish the movie understanding my early life emotions but believing some kids really need medications!I don't think it's fair to give less than 6 to this beautiful animation. But never 10! It has funny moments however I felt depressed most of the time. It has its moments, yet cannot be compared to classics like Lion King.

Inside Out, the 2015 animated film from Pixar, is an absolute cinematic masterpiece that captures the complexities of human emotions in a visually stunning and emotionally resonant way. Directed by Pete Docter, the film takes viewers on a journey through the mind of an 11-year-old girl named Riley, as her emotions - Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear, and Disgust - navigate her life during a challenging period of transition. Here are several reasons why Inside Out is a masterpiece:

Groundbreaking Concept: Inside Out presents a fresh and groundbreaking concept that delves into the inner workings of the human mind and explores the intricate world of emotions. The film personifies emotions as characters who operate in a control center, known as Headquarters, and their interactions and dynamics are brilliantly portrayed. The film's unique concept challenges conventional storytelling and provides an innovative and thought-provoking approach to depicting emotions on screen.

Emotional Depth: Inside Out delves into the complexity of human emotions with remarkable depth and authenticity. It portrays how emotions are intertwined and how they shape our thoughts, memories, and actions. The film masterfully depicts the interplay of emotions, showing how Joy and Sadness are not mutually exclusive, but rather essential for each other's existence. The exploration of Sadness as a crucial emotion, often overlooked in society, is a groundbreaking approach that highlights the importance of embracing all emotions as part of the human experience.

Visual Brilliance: The animation in Inside Out is visually breathtaking. Pixar's attention to detail is evident in every frame, creating a vibrant and immersive world that represents the inner workings of the mind. The creative use of color, lighting, and visual cues to represent different emotions and memories adds depth and richness to the storytelling. The stunning visuals enhance the emotional impact of the film, making it a truly cinematic experience.

Relatable Storytelling: Inside Out tells a universal story that resonates with audiences of all ages. The film depicts the challenges of growing up, dealing with change, and navigating complex emotions in a relatable and heartfelt manner. It explores the struggles of adolescence, the importance of family and friendships, and the emotional journey we all go through as we mature. The story is presented in a way that is accessible to both children and adults, making it a film that can be appreciated by audiences of all generations.

Memorable Characters: The characters in Inside Out are lovable, relatable, and memorable. Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear, and Disgust are not just caricatures of emotions, but fully fleshed-out characters with their own personalities and motivations. Their interactions are both humorous and poignant, creating a deep emotional connection with the audience. The film's endearing characters are a testament to Pixar's ability to create multi-dimensional characters that resonate with audiences long after the credits roll.

Impactful Themes: Inside Out delves into meaningful and impactful themes that are relevant to everyone. The film explores the importance of emotional intelligence, the need to acknowledge and embrace all emotions, and the value of memories and experiences in shaping our identities. It also delves into the complexity of mental health, highlighting the importance of taking care of our emotional well-being. These themes are handled with sensitivity and depth, making Inside Out a thought-provoking and introspective film that prompts meaningful conversations.

Finally, Inside Out is a cinematic masterpiece that pushes the boundaries of storytelling and animation. Its groundbreaking concept, emotional depth, visual brilliance, relatable storytelling, memorable characters, and impactful themes make it a film that resonates with audiences on multiple levels. It is a testament to Pixar's storytelling prowess and their ability to create films that are not only entertaining but also thought-provoking and emotionally resonant. Inside Out is a must-watch for anyone!

A film created both for children and adults, which approaches psychological concepts in an outstandingly creative and accessible manner.
 The Fantasy, Animation, Comedy, Kids & Family movie ‘Inside Out' (2015), directed by Pete Docter, finds an original way of depicting the processes our mind goes through during the times it is taken over by different emotions and memories.
 After freshly moving out with her family to San Francisco, 11-year-old protagonist Riley Andersen, whose mind is controlled by 5 basic emotions: Joy, Sadness, Fear, Disgust, and Anger, is having a hard time getting accustomed to the new environment, thus longing for the old days and bringing back the bittersweet memories of her birthplace. This, however, means that the lead in the Brain Headquarters would be taken by Sadness, which is seen negatively by the other emotions, especially Joy, who took the leader role. In her attempt of getting Sadness to step back from the control panel, the both end up sucked out of the Headquarters, accompanying Riley's core memories, which they now have to find a way to restore, in order to keep Riley's personality, all while Anger, Fear, and Disgust are forced to take charge of Riley's life, with disastrous results.
 What I mostly liked about the movie was the writing, which was done very accurately to portray how emotions and memories help make us who we are. The team managed to illustrate Joy as the most complex emotion, envisioning her as vulnerable and intangible because she was "unapologetically positive". They had the idea about Joy's potential to excessively manipulate youth, creating Riley's "social storms", which is an excellent way of addressing toxic positivity. The key-message that is highlighted throughout the events in the film is that happiness implies feeling sadness as well. Loving someone intrinsically means feeling hurt when we lose them. We NEED sadness in our lives, in order to fully experience joy. We need to cope with painful situations from time to time, in order to grow and become better as a person. ("Crying Helps Me Slow Down And Obsess Over The Weight Of Life's Problems." - Sadness)
 Another great aspect of the movie is its animation, particularly the character design. The team had been assigned a hard job of visualising and turning abstract concepts into understandable for kids animated characters. Not only have they given every character a unique colour and shape pattern (with Anger being shaped like a brick, Joy - a star, Sadness - a teardrop and Fear being tall and thin like a nerve), but they totally moulded each of the emotions from different textures, as well as even making their moves different, accordingly to their personalities (making Fear to be all floppy and dangling all the time and Anger to always keep his stiff, still posture). On top of that, they even went as far as making Joy glow from within, by creating a "sparkly" aura for her, which took a lot of time and efforts.
 All in all, I can admit that having watched the animation more than 3 times doesn't make rewatching it every time any less of a tear-jerker. It is hands down a brilliant production, put together for both children and their parents to enjoy. I absolutely recommend it for a family movie night, not only because it's a much simple way of teaching a child about how their mind works, but also because it's a great tool to help people of any age understand themselves more and learn how to figure out their emotions and besides, it offers some great insight into psychology and neuroscience in a highly uncomplicated way.

Pixar has made movies of all kinds - What if toys had feelings, what if insects had feelings, what if monsters had feelings, what if cars had feelings, what if fishes had feelings, what if rats had feelings. And now they have made Inside Out - what if feelings had feelings? Inside Out is probably one of the most underrated movies that Pixar has made. It was the first original Pixar movie which I didn't get to know about when it released (the first such one was a sequel, Monsters University), and I'm really surprised how this movie gets overlooked so easily.
The way I see it, this movie is a social commentary about how we perceive life with our emotions. Riley here is a metaphor of us, how we feel when we move to a new place and are unable to handle the new life. In such situations we either feel scared, angry or depressed. When Riley starts crying in class, Joy tries to stop Sadness from ruining her memory with a vacuum but ends up destroying all her other memories. This is another metaphor from our lives, where we end up forgetting all our happy memories in times of desperation.
Later on Joy and Sadness are in her memories, where they see Riley's childhood drawing of Bing Bong whom she considered her friend. The plot has been made with a complete sense of nostalgia. When we feel nostalgic, we feel both happiness and sadness at the same time. We are happy because we got to live those times, the time which was better than what we are living at the moment. We are sad because we know that time never stops, and so everyday we are straying further away from when it happened. We will never be able to live the day again, and it shall only stay in our memory.
While Joy and Sadness are not present Fear, Anger and Disgust control her. I don't think I need to explain this. Riley has lost all her happiness and does not feel any sadness. Keep in mind she had previously cried in class, which is something very embarrassing for a ten year old child. As a result she does not want to show her sorrow in front of everyone since she fears people will laugh at her, so instead she tries to cover it with anger and disgust. This is just like how we behave when we are depressed but are also too afraid of what others might think if they learn about it.
And then there is the memory dump, the place where the old memories are forgotten. This is one of the deepest messages that the movie gave us. To save Joy and Sadness and allow them to get out of the pit, Bing Bong readily sacrifices himself. This is because he had always considered himself and Riley friends, and he was ready to sacrifice his own life for this. It also shows how Riley has now lost the memory of Bing Bong due to her depression and frustration, and it is something she will never remember again. This is a metaphor of how we forget the small details from our childhood which gave us joy once we grow out of the phase. It also symbolises that although Bing Bong has been lost forever, Riley's joy and sadness will always remember him. This is similar to how we get nostalgic whenever we see our childhood writings and drawings.
And finally when Joy and Sadness do make it back, then Joy chooses to let Sadness guide Riley. If she wanted she could have guided Riley and make her feel happy about reuniting with her parents. But in that case the moment would have completely lost the impact. So instead Sadness did it, which is why Riley started crying, something she had not done for a long time. This is yet another metaphor of when we are unable to hold our sorrow for too long and burst out crying. As a result her parents are finally able to understand the situation she is in and give her more love.
In the end Riley starts feeling happy, since everyone has understood the value of Joy. She was the first emotion that Riley felt, and the one who guided them all in the time of desperation. All the other emotions came to her afterwards, which is why they are not as emotionally attached to Riley as Joy does. Joy knows what is the best for her, just like how we feel the best thing for our life is what makes us happy.

Just….how? How did Pixar make another flawless film after three films that I would either consider meh or bad? I just don't get it! Let's just make sure Pete Doctor directs every Pixar movie ever and we will be a-ok. I don't want to talk about all the good things with this movie, because let's face it: everyone has done that. Instead, I want to talk about all the things that this Pixar movie does better than all the others. First, I think this is the best voice cast for any Pixar movies prior or after this. The only one that kind of comes close for me is Toy Story 4, but that's for a different review. Biggest highlight is of course the great work of Amy Phoeler as Joy, it was just spot on. Next, comedy. Seeing how the main character is literally the concept of Joy, I would like to think that this movie was going to be funny. And I was right with this being, in my personal opinion, the funniest Pixar movie. Lewis Black as Anger is just a laughing riot to me. He was hilarious! Finally, how can you not talk about this movie without mentioning the ending, with two big emotional parts that really leave a huge impact. The first being the death of Bing Bong, which feels a little like it comes out of nowhere, but you're going to remember it. And, of course, when Riley comes home from running away and the parents also say that they miss the old home….OMG it's so good! The only kind of problem is that Anger is mainly the reason  all the islands get destroyed, and no one addresses it at any moment. But that's minor, and no one is going to be thinking that in their first viewing, I only noticed it in my most previous viewing of the movie anyway. I really think someone should do a deeper dive into this movie, cause it really deserves it. However, I can only praise it for so long. Go to Disney+ and watch this flawless film and to see the best Pixar has to offer!

Inside Out  review 
 	A heartfelt animated movie, "Inside Out", takes you on a rollercoaster of emotions with creative imagination and a look back at some nostalgic moments we might have had in our childhood. Unlike any other, Pixar studios created an original movie of the emotions that go behind a person's mind and made them into having their own personalities. Focused on the mind of a little girl ,Riley her life is shown as typically any perfect childhood. With the presence of the emotion joy it shows her story of her two loving parents raising her and living the life with many moments that one child creates. Including the building of humor, friendship and playing your favorite sport. But as all children go through the other emotions such as sadness, fear ,disgust and anger it will include her experiences. However, her life takes a sudden turn when she has to move with her parents from their hometown Minnesota to San Francisco. Her emotions will be put to the test in adapting to a new lifestyle they're typically unused to. 
	 
											
 To start off , it shows the beginning of the first years in Riley's life. Transitioning from stages to the preteens years of her life. This is where she experiences many emotions and personal likeness and dislikeness. Riley is seen on her journey as she experiences all typical childhood memories. From learning how to walk to talking your first new words. Discovering your least favorite meal to favorite toy to take with you everywhere. The laughter you create and the sad moments you experience. The rewarding moments of receiving a good grade to being upset for losing an important game.
As Riley is growing she has experienced majority exciting emotions until a certain news comes to her attention. She will be moving from her childhood home Minnesota, where she was born, raised, and grew up to miles away into the city of San Francisco. Despite the change , her emotion Joy makes Riley see all this in a positive way. Meeting new friends, decorating a new room and many more ideas.
	Arriving at the new location, Riley is quick to notice the drastic change in seeing her new home. Adapting to the city and less outdoor activity is one of the unfortunate changes making her find new adventures. On her first day of school, she is introduced to her classmates and told to talk a bit more from her time back home. As she recalls some of her favorite memories, the emotion sadness touches her favorite memory, changing Riley's memory to a sad moment and turning it into a sorrowful memory. Joy continues to try and make Riley enjoy the new memories. After they had another similar disagreement Joy and Sadness cause the core 
											
memories to be knocked from their containers and accidentally vacuumed along with them into Riley's emotional interior. With this problem, it leaves the other emotions Fear, Disgust and Anger to run the emotions until the others return changing RIleys behavior. 
Throughout the film it shows the many obstacles and challenges Joy and Sadness must go through to reach the headquarters. Following with revisiting old memories and lifelong imaginary friends. It will take a spin through some future glimpse some being Riley's future boyfriend and many more. Overall this unfortunate event turned out to be a better lesson. The emotions appreciating each other's teamwork to help Riley have the best life she could as she grows up. Enjoying the moments one creates as living life with a positive attitude.
While it seemed like Pixar's morale was rapidly declining, this emotional masterpiece tipped the scales.

Pretty fantastic. The specific look of the characters ran from the familiar (humans, Bing Bong) to the unique, fresh. Colors are extreme, but in a good way. This is comedy, but it's not all just a light-hearted ride. And it's the heavier elements of the story that make this such a fully-realized take on the base concepts here. 
Riley moves with her family half way across the country, to a place far different from her Minnesota hometown; too different, it would seem. Stellar work by the voice-over cast. Poehler is always great. Smart choice in casting Smith as Sadness. She knows her way around some sad, as she clearly showed on The Office. Kind was a great Bing Bong. Kaling was all over Disgust. And Hader was....well...Hader; which means brilliant and funny and just unbeatable. 
The movie does tread a bit close to overly sweet at moments, but it never gets too saccharine, sentimental or dark. There's a wonderful balance between the emotions that show the very real feelings of a kid going through such changes. Overt sweetness that is typical in kids animation is sorta replaced with nostalgia; a common but strong emotion. But along with the fantastical, the eye candy visuals, the depth and cleverness of the screenplay, they always remember to bring the funny. 4 stars

They made sadness ( the character) annoying at the start of the movie, which was intentional a very cool choice, a very good character arc. The score by Michael Giacchino is perfect. Pete Docter and his team have done another brilliant movie, for everyone to enjoy and learn from.

I found this to be second only to Toy Story 3 in the strength of its pull on my emotions. I'm glad that I was already a parent when I saw the movie & wasn't a kid going into it with a blind faith in all things Pixar as it does seem like at least portions of the storyline would be difficult to follow, but watching it in my mid-20s it's clear that this was a film created by and, really, for parents. The score was awesome & the voice acting was among the best that I've ever seen as the casting choices were absolutely impeccable. I found the pixellated aura around Joy & the others to be rather distracting but mostly because it seemed like the rest of the film was very finely animated & ended up with an internal debate over whether they were supposed to seem like they were fading away or not; also, knowing that hair is among the hardest things to animate, I found Joy's immobile hair a bit lacking in nuance. The personality islands stretched my suspension of disbelief a bit & I can imagine retrospectively them going a different direction with the screenplay in the form of the emotions conquering some sort of antagonist made up of the outburst Riley seemed destined for over the move, but I digress. The movie was still very good viewing material exactly how it was. Kudos!

A beautifully animated, well considered examination of the experiences, emotions and thought processes we go through when coming-of-age. It's clever, funny, and emotive, giving something the whole family can enjoy
Inside Out is Pixar's most overrated film.  The characters are insufferable. Many parts make no sense including the cause of the climax.
Believe me it will make you cry prepare your tissues!
When it comes to teaching everyone how emotions work, Inside Out is both clever and practical.
a very well-crafted movie that explores all the different emotions and shows how important they all are.
Inside Out is an amazing movie about all the emotions of a girl named Riley. It is pretty sad at times, but it also is very uplifting and happy. A good movie for all ages.

moving, Sad, surprising, this film is a sum of feelings that must be enjoyed by everyone, Pixar as always doing an excellent job.
One of my favorite Pixar movies.
It shows Riley emotions really well. And Sadness role in core memory before it turned to Joy also portraited very well. I'm a little bit sad for Bing Bong but that's life. Overall, worth it

Inside Out is good movie but needs a lot of work story wise. Everything felt so messy and out of place. Right off the bat it felt like were placed in a scene that were supposed to know what was happening, but didn't. Everyone was attacking Sadness in the first 5 minutes which seemed like a bad way to start the movie. The rest of the movie is decent with dialogue being sometimes funny and the pacing being fine. The animation is also good. There is really nothing amazing in this movie. It is a decent movie that I think needed more time to figure itself out.

Really good watch, would watch again, and can recommend.

This is a wonderfully little story of world building and exploration of the human mind through a young teen girl who is scare of the huge amount of change happening in her life.  The parallel of internal struggle and outward reaction to adversity really sets this movie apart.

The audience is literally taken on a exploration of the mind, and the story is not only fun, but capable of serious philosophical concepts.  Because it exemplifies "show, don't tell" those conversations are compacted into palatable actions by the characters.

This is a movie that might make you laugh, cry or both.

It's hard to believe that someone wouldn't relate to this somehow, and probably more that they wouldn't enjoy it at all.
One of the best, most creative, and strangely impactful animated movies ever!

I'm not really into the Pixar movies and this definitely explains why. The storyline was too weird for me. If this movie had been around when I was a kid, perhaps I would have enjoyed it more. As an adult, I did not.
Wow. There is nothing like this. It's the most innovative movie ever made. And it truly makes you "feel" things.

Inside Out is perhaps the most original work by Pixar. It touched me and spoke to me so much that it instantly became my favourite Pixar movie. It's quite rare that I cry during a movie. This movie is both happy and sad at the same time. The plot is so genious and deep, and the theme is relatable. Easily a masterpiece for me.

The movie has a very interesting premise but is not funny enough to keep me entertained. It took a lot to be engaged and while it was good to kind of imagine personalities, emotions and memories in this spectacular simplified system, the movie left a lot to be desired.

This is so much more than just a kids movie - its message and themes will resonate more with adults. It touches on human emotion, change, coming-of-age, and family. It's a bold, heartfelt, and gorgeously-animated film with a fantastically unique premise and well-fleshed out and emotional (get it?) characters. The voice cast is superb and fit their respective characters perfectly.
A great plot with great characters, animation and a great story.

rt_summary: Riley (Kaitlyn Dias) is a happy, hockey-loving 11-year-old Midwestern girl, but her world turns upside-down when she and her parents move to San Francisco. Riley's emotions -- led by Joy (Amy Poehler) -- try to guide her through this difficult, life-changing event. However, the stress of the move brings Sadness (Phyllis Smith) to the forefront. When Joy and Sadness are inadvertently swept into the far reaches of Riley's mind, the only emotions left in Headquarters are Anger, Fear and Disgust.
